titlePart.title: The Roaring Girl, or Moll Cutpurse

epigraph.l: My case is alter'd, I must work for my living.

castItem.role: SIR ALEXANDER Wengrave, and NEATFOOT his man
JACK Dapper, [son to Sir Davy,] and GULL his page

div.head: To the Comic Play-Readers, Venery and Laughter
div.p: The fashion of play-making I can properly compare to nothing so naturally as the alteration in apparel: for in the time of the great crop-doublet, your huge bombasted plays, quilted with mighty words to lean purposes, was only then in fashion. And as the doublet fell, neater inventions began to set up. Now in the time of spruceness, our plays follow the niceness of our garments: single plots, quaint conceits, lecherous jests, dressed up in hanging sleeves, and those are fit for the times and the termers. Such a kind of light-colour summer stuff, mingled with diverse colours, you shall find this published comedy, good to keep you in an afternoon from dice, at home in your chambers; and for venery you shall find enough for sixpence, but well couched and you mark it, for Venus being a woman passes through the play in doublet in breeches, a brave disguise and a safe one if the statute untie not her codpiece point. The book I make no question but is fit for many of your companies, as well as the person itself, and may be allowed both galley room at the playhouse, and chamber room at your lodging. Worse things I must needs confess the world has taxed her for than has been written of her; but 'tis the excellency of a writer to leave things better than he finds 'em; though some obscene fellow (that cares not what he writes against others, yet keeps a mystical bawdy-house himself, and entertains drunkards to make use of their pockets and vent his private bottle-ale at midnight), though such a one would have ripped up the most nasty vice that ever hell belched forth and presented it to a modest assembly, yet we rather wish in such discoveries, where reputation lies bleeding, a slackness of truth than a fullness of slander.

div.head: Prologus
div.l: A play expected long makes the audience look
For wonders, that each scene should be a book,
Compos'd to all perfection; each one comes
And brings a play in's head with him: up he sums
What he would of a roaring girl have writ;
If that he finds not here, he mews at it.
Only we entreat you think our scene
Cannot speak high, the subject being but mean:
A roaring girl whose notes till now never were
Shall fill with laughter our vast theatre;
That's all which I dare promise: tragic passion,
And such grave stuff, is this day out of fashion.
I see attention sets wide ope her gates
Of hearing, and with covetous list'ning waits,
To know what girl this roaring girl should be,
For of that tribe are many. One is she
That roars at midnight in deep tavern bowls,
That beats the watch, and constables controls;
Another roars i' th' daytime, swears, stabs, gives braves,
Yet sells her soul to the lust of fools and slaves.
Both these are suburb roarers. Then there's beside
A civil city roaring girl, whose pride,
Feasting, and riding, shakes her husband's state,
And leaves him roaring through an iron grate.
None of these roaring girls is ours: she flies
With wings more lofty. Thus her character lies;
Yet what need characters, when to give a guess
Is better than the person to express?
But would you know who 'tis? Would you hear her name?
She is call'd mad Moll; her life, our acts proclaim.

div.head: I.i. [Sebastian's chambers in Sir Alexander's house]
div.stage: Enter Mary Fitzallard disguised like a sempster with a case for bands, and Neatfoot a serving-man with her, with a napkin on his shoulder and a trencher in his hand as from table.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: The young gentleman our young master, Sir Alexander's son, is it into his ears, sweet damsel emblem of fragility, you desire to have a message transported, or to be transcendent?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: A private word or two, sir, nothing else.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: You shall fructify in that which you come for: your pleasure shall be satisfied to your full contentation. I will, fairest tree of generation, watch when our young master is erected, that is to say, up, and deliver him to this your most white hand.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: Thanks, sir.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: And withal certify him that I have culled out for him, now his belly is replenished, a daintier bit or modicum than any lay upon his trencher at dinner. Hath he notion of your name, I beseech your chastity?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: One, sir, of whom he bespake falling bands.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: Falling bands: it shall so be given him. If you please to venture your modesty in the hall amongst a curl-pated company of rude serving-men, and take such as they can set before you, you shall be most seriously and ingeniously welcome.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: I have [dined] indeed already, sir.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: Or will you vouchsafe to kiss the lip of a cup of rich Orleans in the buttery amongst our waiting-women?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: Not now in truth, sir.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: Our young master shall then have a feeling of your being here; presently it shall so be given him.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: I humbly thank you, sir.
But that my bosom
Is full of bitter sorrows, I could smile
To see this formal ape play antic tricks:
But in my breast a poisoned arrow sticks,
And smiles cannot become me. Love woven slightly,
Such as thy false heart makes, wears out as lightly,
But love being truly bred i' th' the soul like mine
Bleeds even to death at the least wound it takes:
The more we quench this [fire], the less it slakes.
Oh, me!

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: A sempster speak with me, sayst thou?

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: Yes, sir, she's there, viva voce, to deliver her auricular confession.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: With me, sweet heart? What is't?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: I have brought home your bands, sir.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Bands? Neatfoot.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Prithee look in, for all the gentlemen are upon rising.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: Yes, sir, a most methodical attendance shall be given.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: And dost hear? If my father call for me, say I am busy with a sempster.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: Yes, sir, he shall know it that you are busied with a needlewoman.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: In's ear, good Neatfoot.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: It shall be so given him. Exit Neatfoot.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Bands? Y'are mistaken, sweet heart, I bespake none. When, where? I prithee, what bands? Let me see them.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: Yes, sir, a bond fast sealed with solemn oaths,
Subscribed unto as I thought with your soul,
Delivered as your deed in sight of heaven.
Is this bond cancell'd? Have you forgot me?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Ha! Life of my life: Sir Guy Fitzallard's daughter!
What has transform'd my love to this strange shape?
Stay, make all sure. So, now speak and be brief,
Because the wolf's at door that lies in wait
To prey upon us both. Albeit mine eyes
Are bless'd by thine, yet this so strange disguise
Holds me with fear and wonder.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: Mine's a loathed sight.
Why from it are you banish'd else so long?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I must cut short my speech. In broken language,
Thus much: sweet Moll, I must thy company shun;
I court another Moll. My thoughts must run

l.ref: As a horse runs that's blind round in a mill,

sp.l: Out every step yet keeping one path still.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: Umh! Must you shun my company? In one knot
Have both our hands by th' hands of heaven been tied,
Now to be broke? I thought me once your bride:
Our fathers did agree on the time when,
And must another bedfellow fill my room?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Sweet maid, let's lose no time. 'Tis in heaven's book
Set down that I must have thee. An oath we took
To keep our vows, but when the knight your father
Was from mine parted, storms began to sit
Upon my covetous father's brow, which fell
From them on me. He reckon'd up what gold
This marriage would draw from him, at which he swore
To lose so much blood could not grieve him more.
He then dissuades me from thee, call'd thee not fair,
And ask'd what is she but a beggar's heir?
He scorn'd thy dowry of five thousand marks.
If such a sum of money could be found,
And I would match with that, he'd not undo it,
Provided his bags might add nothing to it,
But vow'd, if I took thee, nay, more, did swear it,
Save birth from him I nothing should inherit.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: What follows then, my shipwreck?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Dear'st, no:
Tho' wildly in a labyrinth I go,
My end is to meet thee; with a side wind
Must I now sail, else I no haven can find
But both must sink forever. There's a wench
Call'd Moll, mad Moll or merry Moll, a creature
So strange in quality a whole city takes
Note of her name and person. All that affection
I owe to thee on her in counterfeit passion
I spend to mad my father: he believes
I dote upon this roaring girl, and grieves
As it becomes a father for a son
That could be so bewitch'd. Yet I'll go on
This crooked way, sigh still for her, feign dreams
In which I'll talk only of her: these streams
Shall, I hope, force my father to consent
That here I anchor rather than be rent
Upon a rock so dangerous. Art thou pleas'd,
Because thou seest we are waylaid, that I take
A path that's safe, tho' it be far about?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: My prayers with heaven guide thee.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Then I will on.
My father is at hand: kiss and be gone.
Hours shall be watch'd for meetings; I must now,
As men for fear, to a strange idol bow.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I'll guide thee forth; when next we meet
A story of Moll shall make our mirth more sweet.

div.head: [I.ii. The parlour of Sir Alexander's house]
div.stage: Enter Sir Alexander Wengrave, Sir Davy Dapper, Sir Adam Appleton, Goshawk, Laxton, and gentlemen.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: Thanks, good Sir Alexander, for our bounteous cheer.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Fie, fie, in giving thanks you pay too dear.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: When bounty spreads the table, faith, 'twere sin,
At going off, if thanks should not step in.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: No more of thanks, no more. Ay, marry, sir,
Th' inner room was too close. How do you like
This parlour, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: Oh, passing well!

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: What a sweet breath the air casts here, so cool!

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: I like the prospect best.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: See how 'tis furnish'd.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: A very fair, sweet room.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Sir Davy Dapper,
The furniture that doth adorn this room
Cost many a fair grey groat ere it came here,
But good things are most cheap when th' are most dear.
Nay, when you look into my galleries,
How bravely they are trimm'd up, you all shall swear
Y'are highly pleas'd to see what's set down there:
Stories of men and women mix'd together,
Fair ones with foul, like sunshine in wet weather;
Within one square a thousand heads are laid
So close that all of heads the room seems made.
As many faces there fill'd with blithe looks
Show like the promising titles of new books
Writ merrily, the readers being their own eyes,
Which seem to move and to give plaudities.
And here and there, whilst with obsequious ears
Throng'd heaps do listen, a cutpurse thrusts and leers
With hawk's eyes for his prey; I need not show him:
By a hanging villainous look yourselves may know him,
The face is drawn so rarely. Then, sir, below,
The very flower as 'twere waves to and fro,
And like a floating island seems to move
Upon a sea bound in with shores above. Enter Sebastian and M[aster] Greenwit.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: These sights are excellent.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I'll show you all.
Since we are met, make our parting comical.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: This gentleman, my friend, will take his leave, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Ha, take his leave, Sebastian? Who?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: This gentleman.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Your love, sir, has already given me some time,
And if you please to trust my age with more,
It shall pay double interest. Good sir, stay.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: I have been too bold.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Not so, sir. A merry day
'Mongst friends being spent is better than gold sav'd.
Some wine, some wine. Where be these knaves I keep? Enter three or four serving-men, and Neatfoot.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: At your worshipful elbow, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: You are kissing my maids, drinking, or fast asleep.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: Your worship has given it us right.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: You varlets, stir:
Chairs, stools and cushions! Prithee, Sir Davy Dapper,
Make that chair thine.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: 'Tis but an easy gift,
And yet I thank you for it, sir; I'll take it.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: A chair for old Sir Adam Appleton.

sp.speaker: NEATFOOT
sp.l: A back friend to your worship.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Marry, good Neatfoot,
I thank thee for it: back friends sometimes are good.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Pray make that stool your perch, good M[aster] Goshawk.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: I stoop to your lure, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Son Sebastian,
Take Master Greenwit to you.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Sit, dear friend.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Nay, Master Laxton. Furnish Master Laxton
With what he wants, a stone: a stool I would say,
A stool.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: I had rather stand, sir. Exeunt servants.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I know you had, good Master Laxton. So, so.
Now here's a mess of friends, and, gentlemen,
Because time's glass shall not be running long,
I'll quicken it with a pretty tale.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Good tales do well
In these bad days, where vice does so excel.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Begin, Sir Alexander.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Last day I met
An aged man upon whose head was scor'd
A debt of just so many years as these
Which I owe to my grave: the man you all know.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: His name I pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Nay, you shall pardon me;
But when he saw me, with a sigh that brake,
Or seem'd to break, his heartstrings, thus he spake:
"Oh, my good knight," says he, and then his eyes
Were richer even by that which made them poor,
They had spent so many tears they had no more.
"Oh, sir," says he, "you know it, for you ha' seen
Blessings to rain upon mine house and me:
Fortune, who slaves men, was my slave; her wheel
Hath spun me golden threads, for, I thank heaven,
I ne'er had but one cause to curse my stars."
I ask'd him then what that one cause might be.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: So, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: He paus'd, and as we often see
A sea so much becalm'd there can be found
No wrinkle on his brow, his waves being drown'd
In their own rage, but when th' imperious wind[s]
Use strange invisible tyranny to shake
Both heaven's and earth's foundation at their noise,
The seas, swelling with wrath to part that fray,
Rise up and are more wild, more mad, than they:
Even so this good old man was by my question
Stirr'd up to roughness, you might see his gall
Flow even in's eyes. Then grew he fantastical.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Fantastical? Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Yes, and talk['d] oddly.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Pray, sir, proceed:
How did this old man end?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Marry, sir, thus:
He left his wild fit to read o'er his cards,
Yet then, though age cast snow on all his hairs,
He joy'd because, says he, "The god of gold
Has been to me no niggard: that disease
Of which all old men sicken, avarice,
Never infected me."

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: [Aside] He means not himself, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: "For, like a lamp
Fed with continual oil, I spend and throw
My light to all that need it, yet have still
Enough to serve myself. Oh, but," quoth he,
"Tho' heaven's dew fall thus on this aged tree,
I have a son that like a wedge doth cleave
My very heart-root."

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Had he such a son?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: [Aside] Now I do smell a fox strongly.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Let's see: no, Master Greenwit is not yet
So mellow in years as he; but as like Sebastian,
Just like my son Sebastian, such another.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p: [Aside] How finely like a fencer my father fetches his by-blows to hit me, but if I beat you not at your own weapon of subtlety--

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: "This son," saith he, "that should be
The column and main arch unto my house,
The crutch unto my age, becomes a whirlwind
Shaking the firm foundation."

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: 'Tis some prodigal.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: [Aside] Well shot, old Adam Bell!

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: "No city monster neither, no prodigal,
But sparing, wary, civil, and, tho' wifeless,
An excellent husband, and such a traveller,
He has more tongues in his head than some have teeth."

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: I have but two in mine.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: So sparing and so wary?
What then could vex his father so?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Oh, a woman!

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: A flesh-fly, that can vex any man.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: A scurvy woman,
On whom the passionate old man swore he doted;
A creature, saith he, nature hath brought forth
To mock the sex of woman. It is a thing
One knows not how to name; her birth began
Ere she was all made. 'Tis woman more than man,
Man more than woman, and, which to none can hap,
The sun gives her two shadows to one shape;
Nay, more, let this strange thing walk, stand or sit,
No blazing star draws more eyes after it.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: A monster, 'tis some monster.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: She's a varlet.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: [Aside] Now is my cue to bristle.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: A naughty pack.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Ha, boy?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: What's false? I say she's naught.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I say that tongue
That dares speak so but yours sticks in the throat
Of a rank villain; set yourself aside--

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: So, sir, what then?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Any here else had lied.
(Aside) I think I shall fit you!

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Lie?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Doth this concern him?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Ah, sirrah boy!
Is your blood heated? Boils it? Are you stung?
I'll pierce you deeper yet.--Oh, my dear friends,
I am that wretched father, this that son
That sees his ruin yet headlong on doth run!

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Will you love such a poison?

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Fie, fie!

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Y'are all mad!

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Th' art sick at heart, yet feel'st it not. Of all these,
What gentleman but thou, knowing his disease
Mortal, would shun the cure? Oh, Master Greenwit,
Would you to such an idol bow?

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Not I, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Here's Master Laxton: has he mind to a woman
As thou hast?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: No, not I, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Sir, I know it.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Their good parts are so rare, their bad so common,
I will have nought to do with any woman.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: 'Tis well done, Master Laxton.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Oh, thou cruel boy,
Thou wouldst with lust an old man's life destroy;
Because thou seest I'm half-way in my grave,
Thou shovel'st dust upon me: would thou mightest have
Thy wish, most wicked, most unnatural!

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Why, sir, 'tis thought Sir Guy Fitzallard's daughter
Shall wed your son Sebastian.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Sir Davy Dapper,
I have upon my knees woo'd this fond boy
To take that virtuous maiden.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Hark you, a word, sir.
You on your knees have curs'd that virtuous maiden
And me for loving her, yet do you now
Thus baffle me to my face? [Wear] not your knees
In such entreats; give me Fitzallard's daughter.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I'll give thee rats-bane rather!

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Well, then you know
What dish I mean to feed upon.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Hark, gentlemen, he swears
To have this cutpurse drab to spite my gall.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: Master Sebastian!

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I am deaf to you all.
I'm so bewitch'd, so bound to my desires,
Tears, prayers, threats, nothing can quench out those fires
That burn within me. Exit Sebastian.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Her blood shall quench it then.--
Lose him not, oh, dissuade him, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: He shall be wean'd, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Before his eyes
Lay down his shame, my grief, his miseries.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: No more, no more, away! Exeunt all but Sir Alexander.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I wash a negro,
Losing both pains and cost; but take thy flight:
I'll be most near thee when I'm least in sight.
Wild buck, I'll hunt thee breathless; thou shalt run on,
But I will turn thee when I'm not thought upon.
Now, sirrah, what are you? Leave your ape's tricks and speak!

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: A letter from my captain to your worship.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Oh, oh, now I remember: 'tis to prefer thee into my service.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: To be a shifter under your worship's nose of a clean trencher when there's a good bit upon't.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Troth, honest fellow. [Aside] Humh, ha, let me see.
This knave shall be the axe to hew that down
At which I stumble; h'as a face that promiseth
Much of a villain. I will grind his wit,
And if the edge prove fine make use of it.--
Come hither, sirrah. Canst thou be secret, ha?

l.ref: As two crafty attorneys plotting the undoing of their clients.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Didst never, as thou hast walk'd about this town,
Hear of a wench call'd Moll, mad, merry Moll?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Moll Cutpurse, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: The same. Dost thou know her then?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: As well as I know 'twill rain upon Simon and Jude's day next. I will sift all the taverns i' th' city and drink half-pots with all the watermen a' th' Bankside, but if you will, sir, I'll find her out.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: That task is easy; do 't then. Hold thy hand up.
What's this? Is't burnt?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: No, sir, no, a little sing'd with making fireworks.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Giving him money] There's money, spend it; that being spent, fetch more.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Oh, sir, that all the poor soldiers in England had such a leader! For fetching, no water-spaniel is like me.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: This wench we speak of strays so from her kind
Nature repents she made her. 'Tis a mermaid
Has toll'd my son to shipwreck.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: I'll cut her comb for you.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I'll tell out gold for thee then; hunt her forth,

l.ref: Cast out a line hung full of silver hooks

sp.l: To catch her to thy company: deep spendings
May draw her that's most chaste to a man's bosom.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: The jingling of golden bells and a good fool with a hobbyhorse will draw all the whores i' th' town to dance in a morris.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Or rather--for that's best, they say sometimes
She goes in breeches--follow her as her man.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: And when her breeches are off, she shall follow me.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Beat all thy brains to serve her.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Zounds, sir, as country wenches beat cream till butter comes.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Play thou the subtle spider, weave fine nets
To ensnare her very life.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Her life?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Yes, suck
Her heart-blood if thou canst; twist thou but cords
To catch her, I'll find law to hang her up.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Spoke like a worshipful bencher.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Trace all her steps; at this she-fox's den
Watch what lambs enter: let me play the shepherd
To save their throats from bleeding and cut hers.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: This is the goll shall do't.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Be firm and gain me
Ever thine own. This done, I entertain thee:
How is thy name?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: My name sir is Ralph Trapdoor, honest Ralph.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Trapdoor, be like thy name, a dangerous step
For her to venture on, but unto me--

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: As fast as your sole to your boot or shoe, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Hence then, be little seen here as thou canst.
I'll still be at thine elbow.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: The trapdoor's set.
Moll, if you budge y'are gone; this me shall crown:
A roaring boy the Roaring Girl puts down.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: God-a-mercy, lose no time.

div.head: [II.i.] The three shops open in a rank
div.stage: The first a pothecary's shop, the next a feather shop, the third a sempster's shop: Mistress Gallipot in the first, Mistress Tiltyard in the next, Master Openwork and his wife in the third. To them enters Laxton, Goshawk and Greenwit.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Gentlemen, what is't you lack? What is't you buy? See fine bands and ruffs, fine lawns, fine cambrics! What is't you lack, gentlemen, what is't you buy?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Yonder's the shop.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Is that she?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: She that minces tobacco.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Ay, she's a gentlewoman born, I can tell you, tho' it be her hard fortune now to shred Indian pot-herbs.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Oh, sir, 'tis many a good woman's fortune, when her husband turns bankrout, to begin with pipes and set up again.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: And indeed the raising of the woman is the lifting up of the man's head at all times: if one flourish, t'other will bud as fast, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Come, th' art familiarly acquainted there, I grope that.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: And you grope no better i' th' dark, you may chance lie i' th' ditch when y'are drunk.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Go, th' art a mystical lecher.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I will not deny but my credit may take up an ounce of pure smoke.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: May take up an ell of pure smock. Away, go! [Aside] 'Tis the closest striker. Life, I think he commits venery foot deep; no man's aware on't. I like a palpable smockster go to work so openly with the tricks of art that I'm as apparently seen as a naked boy in a vial, and were it not for a gift of treachery that I have in me to betray my friend when he puts most trust in me--mass, yonder he is too--and by his injury to make good my access to her, I should appear as defective in courting as a farmer's son the first day of his feather that doth nothing at court but woo the hangings and glass windows for a month together, and some broken waiting-woman forever after. I find those imperfections in my venery that were 't not for flattery and falsehood, I should want discourse and impudence, and he that wants impudence among women is worthy to be kick'd out at beds' feet. He shall not see me yet.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: Troth, this is finely shred.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Oh, women are the best mincers.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: 'T had been a good phrase for a cook's wife, sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: But 'twill serve generally, like the front of a new almanac, as thus: calculated for the meridian of cooks' wives, but generally for all Englishwomen.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Nay, you shall ha't, sir, I have fill'd it for you. She puts it to the fire.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: The pipe's in a good hand, and I wish mine always so.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: But not to be us'd a' that fashion.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Oh, pardon me, sir, I understand no French.
I pray be cover'd. [Handing Goshawk a pipe] Jack, a pipe of rich smoke.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Rich smoke? That's sixpence a pipe, is't?

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: To me, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: [Aside to Laxton] Be not forgetful: respect my credit, seem strange. Art and wit makes a fool of suspicion; pray be wary.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: [Aside to Mistress Gallipot] Push, I warrant you!--Come, how is't, gallants?

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: Pure and excellent.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I thought 'twas good, you were grown so silent; you are like those that love not to talk at victuals, tho' they make a worse noise i' the nose than a common fiddler's prentice and discourse a whole supper with snuffling. [Aside to Mistress Gallipot] I must speak a word with you anon.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: [Aside to Laxton] Make your way wisely then.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Oh, what else, sir? He's perfection itself, full of manners, but not an acre of ground belonging to ['im].

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: Ay, and full of form: h'as ne'er a good stool in's chamber.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: But above all religious: he preyeth daily upon elder brothers.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: And valiant above measure; h'as run three streets from a sergeant.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Puh, puh!
sp.stage: He blows tobacco in their faces.
sp.p: GREENWIT, GOSHAWK
Oh, puh, ho, ho! [They move away.]

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: So, so.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: What's the matter now, sir?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I protest I'm in extreme want of money: if you can supply me now with any means, you do me the greatest pleasure, next to the bounty of your love, as ever poor gentleman tasted.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: What's the sum would pleasure ye, sir? Tho' you deserve nothing less at my hands.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Why, 'tis but for want of opportunity, thou know'st. [Aside] I put her off with opportunity still. By this light, I hate her but for means to keep me in fashion with gallants, for what I take from her I spend upon other wenches. Bear her in hand still; she has wit enough to rob her husband, and I ways enough to consume the money.--[Approaching Goshawk from behind and slapping him on the back] Why, how now? What, the chincough?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Thou hast the cowardliest trick to come before a man's face and strangle him ere he be aware! I could find in my heart to make a quarrel in earnest.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Pox and thou dost--thou know'st I never use to fight with my friends--thou'll but lose thy labour in't. Enter J[ack] Dapper and his man Gull.
Jack Dapper!

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: Monsieur Dapper, I dive down to your ankles.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Save ye gentlemen, all three in a peculiar salute.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: [Aside to Laxton] He were ill to make a lawyer: he dispatches three at once.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: So, well said.
But is this of the same tobacco, Mistress Gallipot?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: The same you had at first, sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I wish it no better: this will serve to drink at my chamber.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Shall we taste a pipe on't?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Not of this, by my troth, gentlemen; I have sworn before you.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: What, not Jack Dapper?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Pardon me, sweet Jack, I'm sorry I made such a rash oath, but foolish oaths must stand. Where art going, Jack?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Faith, to buy one feather.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: [Aside] One feather? The fool's peculiar still.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Gull.

sp.speaker: GULL
sp.p: Master.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Here's three halfpence for your ordinary, boy; meet me an hour hence in Paul's.

sp.speaker: GULL
sp.p: How! Three single halfpence! Life, this will scarce serve a man in sauce, a hal'p'orth of mustard, a hal'p'orth of oil, and a hal'p'orth of vinegar. What's left then for the pickle herring? This shows like small beer i' th' morning after a great surfeit of wine o'ernight. He could spend his three pound last night in a supper amongst girls and brave bawdy-house boys; I thought his pockets cackl'd not for nothing. These are the eggs of three pound; I'll go sup 'em up presently. Exit Gull.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: [Aside, counting his money] Eight, nine, ten angels. Good wench, i'faith, and one that loves darkness well: she puts out a candle with the best tricks of any drugster's wife in England; but that which mads her, I rail upon opportunity still and take no notice on't. The other night she would needs lead me into a room with a candle in her hand to show me a naked picture, where no sooner entered but the candle was sent of an arrant; now I not intending to understand her, but, like a puny at the inns of venery, call'd for another light innocently: thus reward I all her cunning with simple mistaking. I know she cozens her husband to keep me, and I'll keep her honest as long as I can to make the poor man some part of amends: an honest mind of a whoremaster!--How think you amongst you? What, a fresh pipe? Draw in a third man.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: No, you're a hoarder; you engross by th' ounces. At the feather shop now

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Puh, I like it not.

sp.speaker: [MISTRESS] TILTYARD
sp.p: What feather is't you'ld have, sir?
These are most worn and most in fashion
Amongst the beaver gallants, the stone riders,
The private stage's audience, the twelvepenny-stool gentlemen:
I can inform you 'tis the general feather.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: And therefore I mislike it; tell me of general!
Now a continual Simon and Jude's rain
Beat all your feathers as flat down as pancakes.
Show me a spangled feather.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS TILTYARD
sp.p: Oh, to go
A-feasting with? You'd have it for a [hench]-boy;
You shall. At the sempster's shop now

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: Mass, I had quite forgot
His honour's footman was here last night, wife.
Ha' you done with my lord's shirt?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: What's that to you, sir?
I was this morning at his honour's lodging
Ere such a [snail] as you crept out of your shell.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: Oh, 'twas well done, good wife!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: I hold it better, sir, than if you had done 't yourself.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: Nay, so say I. But is the countess's smock almost done, mouse?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Here, yes, the cambric, sir, but wants, I fear me.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: I'll resolve you of that presently.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: [Hoyda]! Oh, audacious groom,
Dare you presume to noblewomen's linen?
Keep you your yard to measure shepherd's holland!
I must confine you, I see that. At the tobacco shop now.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: What say you to this gear?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I dare the arrant's[t] critic in tobacco
To lay one fault upon't. Enter Moll in a frieze jerkin and a black safeguard.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Life, yonder's Moll!

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Moll? Which Moll?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Honest Moll.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Prithee, let's call her. Moll!
Moll, Moll, pist, Moll!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: A pipe of good tobacco, Moll?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Nay, Moll, puh! Prithee hark, but one word, i'faith.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Well, what is't?

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.p: Prithee come hither, sirrah.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: [Aside] Heart, I would give but too much money to be nibbling with that wench! Life, sh'as the spirit of four great parishes, and a voice that will drown all the city; methinks a brave captain might get all his soldiers upon her and ne'er be beholding to a company of Mile End milksops, if he could come on and come off quick enough. Such a Moll were a marrow-bone before an Italian; he would cry bona roba till his ribs were nothing but bone. I'll lay hard siege to her; money is that aqua fortis that eats into many a maidenhead: where the walls are flesh and blood, I'll ever pierce through with a golden auger.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Now thy judgment, Moll: is't not good?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Yes, faith, 'tis very good tobacco. How do you sell an ounce? Farewell. God b'i'you, Mistress Gallipot.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Why, Moll, Moll!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I cannot stay now, i'faith. I am going to buy a shag ruff; the shop will be shut in presently.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: 'Tis the maddest, fantastical'st girl: I never knew so much flesh and so much nimbleness put together.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: She slips from one company to another, like a fat eel between a Dutchman's fingers. [Aside] I'll watch my time for her.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Some will not stick to say she's a man
And some both man and woman.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: That were excellent: she might first cuckold the husband and then make him do as much for the wife. The feather shop again.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Save you. How does Mistress Tiltyard?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Moll.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Jack Dapper.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: How dost, Moll?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I'll tell thee by and by; I go but to th' next shop.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Thou shalt find me here this hour about a feather.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Nay, and a feather hold you in play a whole hour, a goose will last you all the days of your life.
Let me see a good shag ruff.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: Mistress Mary, that shalt thou i'faith, and the best in the shop.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: How now! Greetings? Love-terms with a pox between you! Have I found out one of your haunts? I send you for hollands, and you're i' th' low countries with a mischief. I'm serv'd with good ware by th' shift, that makes it lie dead so long upon my hands: I were as good shut up shop, for when I open it I take nothing.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: Nay, and you fall a-ringing once the devil cannot stop you. I'll out of the belfry as fast as I can. Moll.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Get you from my shop.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I come to buy.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: I'll sell ye nothing; I warn ye my house and shop.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: You goody Openwork, you that prick out a poor living
And sews many a bawdy skin-coat together,
Thou private pandress between shirt and smock,
I wish thee for a minute but a man:
Thou shouldst never use more shapes. But as th' art
I pity my revenge: now my spleen's up,
I would not mock it willingly.
sp.stage: Enter a Fellow with a long rapier by his side.
sp.p: Ha! Be thankful.
Now I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Marry, hang thee;
I never ask'd forgiveness in my life.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: You, goodman swine's-face!

sp.speaker: FELLOW
sp.p: What, will you murder me?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: You remember, slave, how you abus'd me t'other night in a tavern?

sp.speaker: FELLOW
sp.p: Not I, by this light.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: No, but by candlelight you did. You have tricks to save your oaths, reservations have you, and I have reserved somewhat for you. [Strikes him.] As you like that, call for more; you know the sign again.

sp.speaker: FELLOW
sp.p: Pox on't, had I brought any company along with me to have borne witness on't; 'twould ne'er have griev'd me; but to be struck and nobody by, 'tis my ill fortune still. Why, tread upon a worm, they say 'twill turn tail, but indeed a gentleman should have more manners. Exit Fellow.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Gallantly performed, i'faith, Moll, and manfully! I love thee forever for't! Base rogue! Had he offer'd but the least counterbuff, by this hand I was prepared for him.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: You prepared for him! Why should you be prepared for him? Was he any more than a man?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: No, nor so much by a yard and a handful London measure.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Why do you speak this then? Do you think I cannot ride a stone horse unless one lead him by th' snaffle?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Yes, and sit him bravely; I know thou canst, Moll. 'Twas but an honest mistake through love, and I'll make amends for't any way. Prithee, sweet, plump Moll, when shall thou and I go out a' town together?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Whither? To Tyburn prithee?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Mass, that's out a' town indeed; thou hang'st so many jests upon thy friends still. I mean honestly to Brainford, Staines or Ware.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: What to do there?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Nothing but be merry and lie together; I'll hire a coach with four horses.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I thought 'twould be a beastly journey. You may leave out one well: three horses will serve if I play the jade myself.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Nay, push, th' art such another kicking wench! Prithee be kind and let's meet.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: 'Tis hard but we shall meet, sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Nay, but appoint the place then. [Giving her money] There's ten angels in fair gold, Moll; you see I do not trifle with you. Do but say thou wilt meet me, and I'll have a coach ready for thee.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Why, here's my hand I'll meet you, sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: [Aside] Oh, good gold!--The place, sweet Moll?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: It shall be your appointment.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Somewhat near Holborn, Moll.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: In Gray's Inn Fields then.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I'll meet you there.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: The hour?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Three.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: That will be time enough to sup at Brainford. Fall from them to the other.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: I am of such a nature, sir, I cannot endure the house when she scolds. Sh' has a tongue will be [heard] further in a still morning than Saint Antling's bell. She rails upon me for foreign wenching, that I being a freeman must needs keep a whore i' th' suburbs, and seek to impoverish the liberties. When we fall out, I trouble you still to make all whole with my wife.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: No trouble at all; 'tis a pleasure to me to join things together.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: Go thy ways. [Aside] I do this but to try thy honesty, Goshawk. The feather shop

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: How lik'st thou this, Moll?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Oh, singularly! You're fitted now for a bunch. [Aside] He looks for all the world with those spangled feathers like a nobleman's bedpost! The purity of your wench would I fain try; she seems like Kent, unconquered, and I believe as many wiles are in her. Oh, the gallants of these times are shallow lechers; they put not their courtship home enough to a wench. 'Tis impossible to know what woman is thoroughly honest, because she's ne'er thoroughly tried; I am of that certain belief there are more queans in this town of their own making than of any man's provoking. Where lies the slackness then? Many a poor soul would down, and there's nobody will push 'em:
Women are courted but ne'er soundly tried,
As many walk in spurs that never ride. The sempster's shop.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Oh, abominable!

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Nay, more: I tell you in private, he keeps a whore i' th' suburbs.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Oh, spital dealing! I came to him a gentlewoman born. I'll show you mine arms when you please, sir.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: [Aside] I had rather see your legs and begin that way.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: 'Tis well known he took me from a lady's service, where I was well beloved of the steward; I had my Latin tongue and a spice of the French before I came to him, and now doth he keep a suburbian whore under my nostrils.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: There's ways enough to cry quit with him; hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: There's a friend worth a million.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: [Aside] I'll try one spear against your chastity, Mistress Tiltyard, though it prove too short by the [burr]. Enter Ralph Trapdoor.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: [Aside] Mass, here she is! I'm bound already to serve her, tho' it be but a sluttish trick.--Bless my hopeful young mistress with long life and great limbs! Send her the upper hand of all bailiffs and their hungry adherents!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: How now! What art thou?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: A poor, ebbing gentleman that would gladly wait for the young flood of your service.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: My service! What should move you to offer your service to me, sir?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: The love I bear to your heroic spirit and masculine womanhood.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: So, sir, put case we should retain you to us, what parts are there in you for a gentlewoman's service?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Of two kinds, right worshipful, movable and immovable: movable to run of arrants, and immovable to stand when you have occasion to use me.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: What strength have you?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Strength, Mistress Moll? I have gone up into a steeple and stayed the great bell as 't has been ringing, stopp'd a windmill going.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: And never struck down yourself?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Stood as upright as I do at this present. Molls trips up his heels; he falls.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Come, I pardon you for this; it shall be no disgrace to you: I have struck up the heels of the high German's size ere now. What, not stand?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: I am of that nature where I love, I'll be at my mistress' foot to do her service.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Why, well said. But say your mistress should receive injury: have you the spirit of fighting in you? Durst you second her?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Life, I have kept a bridge myself and drove seven at a time before me.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Ay?
TRAPDOOR aside
But they were all Lincolnshire bullocks, by my troth.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Well, meet me in Gray's Inn Fields between three and four this afternoon, and upon better consideration we'll retain you.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: I humbly thank your good mistress-ship.
[Aside] I'll crack your neck for this kindness. Exit Trapdoor. Moll meets Laxton.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Remember: three.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Nay, if I fail you, hang me.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Good wench, i'faith. Then Openwork

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Who's this?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: 'Tis I, Moll.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Prithee tend thy shop and prevent bastards.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: We'll have a pint of the same wine, i'faith, Moll. [Exeunt Moll and Openwork.] The bell rings.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Hark the bell rings; come, gentlemen.
Jack Dapper, where shall's all munch?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I am for Parker's ordinary.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: He's a good guest to 'm; he deserves his board:
He draws all the gentlemen in a term-time thither.
We'll be your followers, Jack, lead the way.

Look you, by my faith, the fool has feather'd his nest well. Exeunt gallants [Laxton, Goshawk, Greenwit, Jack Dapper]. Enter Master Gallipot, Master Tiltyard, and servants with water-spaniels and a duck.

sp.speaker: TILTYARD
sp.p: Come, shut up your shops. Where's Master Openwork?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Nay, ask not me, Master Tiltyard.

sp.speaker: TILTYARD
sp.p: Where's his water-dog? Puh-pist-her-her-pist!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Come, wenches, come, we're going all to Hogsden.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: To Hogsden, husband?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Ay, to Hogsden, pigsney.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: I'm not ready, husband.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p:
Faith, that's well. Hum-pist-pist!
Spits in the dog's mouth .
Come, Mistress Openwork, you are so long.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: I have no joy of my life, Master Gallipot.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Push, let your boy lead his water-spaniel along and we'll show you the bravest sport at Parlous Pond. Hey Trug, hey Trug, hey Trug! Here's the best duck in England, except my wife.
sp.l: Hey, hey, hey, fetch, fetch, fetch, come let's away;
Of all the year this is the sportfull'st day.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: If a man have a free will, where should the use
More perfect shine than in his will to love?
All creatures have their liberty in that,
sp.stage: Enter Sir Alexander and listens to him.
sp.l: Tho' else kept under servile yoke and fear;
The very bondslave has his freedom there.
Amongst a world of creatures voic'd and silent
Must my desires wear fetters? [Aside] Yea, are you
So near? Then I must break with my heart's truth,
Meet grief at a back way; well.--Why, suppose
The two-leav'd tongues of slander or of truth
Pronounce Moll loathsome: if before my love
She appear fair, what injury have I?
I have the thing I like. In all things else
Mine own eye guides me, and I find 'em prosper.
Life, what should ail it now? I know that man
Ne'er truly loves, if he gainsay 't he lies,
That winks and marries with his father's eyes.
I'll keep mine own wide open.
sp.stage: Enter Moll and a Porter with a viol on his back.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] Here's brave willfulness,
A made match. Here she comes; they met a' purpose.

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.p: Must I carry this great fiddle to your chamber, Mistress Mary?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Fiddle, goodman hog-rubber? Some of these porters bear so much for others they have no time to carry wit for themselves.

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.p: To your own chamber, Mistress Mary?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Who'll hear an ass speak? Whither else, goodman pageant-bearer? They're people of the worst memories. Exit Porter.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p: Why, 'twere too great a burthen, love, to have them carry things in their minds and a' their backs together.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Pardon me, sir, I thought not you so near.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] So, so, so.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p: I would be nearer to thee, and in that fashion
That makes the best part of all creatures honest.
No otherwise I wish it.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Sir, I am so poor to requite you, you must look for nothing but thanks of me. I have no humour to marry: I love to lie a' both sides a' th' bed myself; and again a' th' other side, a wife, you know, ought to be obedient, but I fear me I am too headstrong to obey, therefore I'll ne'er go about it. I love you so well, sir, for your good will I'd be loath you should repent your bargain after, and therefore we'll ne'er come together at first. I have the head now of myself and am man enough for a woman; marriage is but a chopping and changing, where a maiden loses one head and has a worse i' th' place.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] The most comfortablest answer from a roaring girl
That ever mine ears drunk in.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p: This were enough
Now to affright a fool forever from thee,
When 'tis the music that I love thee for.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] There's a boy spoils all again.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Believe it, sir, I am not of that disdainful temper, but I could love you faithfully.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] A pox on you for that word! I like you not now:
Y'are a cunning roarer; I see that already.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: But sleep upon this once more, sir, you may chance shift a mind tomorrow. Be not too hasty to wrong yourself; never while you live, sir, take a wife running: many have run out at heels that have done 't. You see, sir, I speak against myself, and if every woman would deal with their suitor so honestly, poor younger brothers would not be so often gull'd with old cozening widows that turn o'er all their wealth in trust to some kinsman and make the poor gentleman work hard for a pension. Fare you well, sir.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p: Nay, prithee, one word more.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] How do I wrong this girl: she puts him off still!

sp.speaker: MOLL
SEBASTIAN
sp.p: And so we parted, my too-cursed fate.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] She is but cunning, gives him longer time in't. Enter a Tailor.

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: Mistress Moll, Mistress Moll: so ho ho so ho!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: There boy, there boy! What, dost thou go a-hawking after me with a red clout on thy finger?

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: I forgot to take measure on you for your new breeches.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] Hoyda! Breeches! What, will he marry a monster with two trinkets? What age is this? If the wife go in breeches, the man must wear long coats like a fool.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: What fiddling's here? Would not the old pattern have serv'd your turn?

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: You change the fashion; you say you'll have the great Dutch slop, Mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Why, sir, I say so still.

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: Your breeches then will take up a yard more.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Well, pray look it be put in then.

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: It shall stand round and full, I warrant you,

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Pray make 'em easy enough.

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: I know my fault now: t'other was somewhat stiff between the legs; I'll make these open enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.p: [Aside] Here's good gear towards! I have brought up my son to marry a Dutch slop and a French doublet, a codpiece-daughter!

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: So, I have gone as far as I can go.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Why then, farewell.

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: If you go presently to your chamber, Mistress Mary, pray send me the measure of your thigh by some honest body.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Well, sir, I'll send it by a porter presently. Exit Moll.

sp.speaker: TAILOR
sp.p: So you had need: it is a lusty one; both of them would make any porter's back ache in England. Exit Tailor.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I have examined the best part of man,
Reason and judgment, and in love they tell me
They leave me uncontroll'd: he that is sway'd
By an unfeeling blood past heat of love,
His springtime must needs err; his watch ne'er goes right
That sets his dial by a rusty clock.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Coming forward] So, and which is that rusty clock, sir? You?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: The clock at Ludgate, sir; it ne'er goes true.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: But thou goest falser: not thy father's cares
Can keep thee right. When that insensible work
Obeys the workman's art, lets off the hour
And stops again when time is satisfied;
But thou runn'st on, and judgment, thy main wheel,
Beats by all stops, as if the work would break
Begun with long pains for a minute's ruin,
Much like a suffering man brought up with care
At last bequeath'd to shame and a short prayer.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I taste you bitterer than I can deserve, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Who has bewitch['d] thee, son? What devil or drug
Hath wrought upon the weakness of thy blood
And betray'd all her hopes to ruinous folly?
Oh, wake from drowsy and enchanted shame,
Wherein thy soul sits with a golden dream,
Flatter'd and poisoned! I am old, my son;
Oh, let me prevail quickly,
For I have weightier business of mine own
Than to chide thee: I must not to my grave
As a drunkard to his bed, whereon he lies
Only to sleep and never cares to rise.
Let me dispatch in time; come no more near her.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Not honestly? Not in the way of marriage?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: What, sayst thou marriage? In what place, the sessions-house? And who shall give the bride, prithee, an indictment?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Sir, now ye take part with the world to wrong her.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Why, wouldst thou fain marry to be pointed at?
Alas, the number's great; do not o'erburden 't.
Why, as good marry a beacon on a hill,
Which all the country fix their eyes upon
As her thy folly dotes on. If thou long'st
To have the story of thy infamous fortunes,
Serve for discourse in ordinaries and taverns,
Th' art in the way; or to confound thy name,
Keep on, thou canst not miss it; or to strike
Thy wretched father to untimely coldness,
Keep the left hand still, it will bring thee to't.
Yet if no tears wrung from thy father's eyes,
Nor sighs that fly in sparkles from his sorrows,
Had power to alter what is willful in thee,
Methinks her very name should fright thee from her
And never trouble me.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Why is the name of Moll so fatal, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Marry], one, sir, where suspect is ent'red,
For seek all London from one end to t'other
More whores of that name than of any ten other.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: What's that to her? Let those blush for themselves.
Can any guilt in others condemn her?
I've vow'd to love her: let all storms oppose me
That ever beat against the breast of man,
Nothing but death's black tempest shall divide us.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Oh, folly that can dote on nought but shame!

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Put case a wanton itch runs through one name
More than another: is that name the worse
Where honesty sits possess'd in't? It should rather
Appear more excellent and deserve more praise
When through foul mists a brightness it can raise.
Why, there are of the devil's honest gentlemen,
And well descended, keep an open house,
And some a' th' good man's that are arrant knaves.
He hates unworthily that by rote contemns,
For the name neither saves nor yet condemns.
And for her honesty, I have made such proof an't
In several forms, so nearly watch'd her ways,
I will maintain that strict against an army,
Excepting you my father. Here's her worst:
Sh' has a bold spirit that mingles with mankind,
But nothing else comes near it, and oftentimes
Through her apparel somewhat shames her birth,
But she is loose in nothing but in mirth.
Would all Molls were no worse.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] This way I toil in vain and give but aim
To infamy and ruin. He will fall;
My blessing cannot stay him: all my joys
Stand at the brink of a devouring flood
And will be willfully swallowed, willfully,
But why so vain? Let all these tears be lost:
I'll pursue her to shame, and so all's cross'd. Exit Sir Alexander.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: He is gone with some strange purpose, whose effect
Will hurt me little if he shoot so wide,
To think I love so blindly. I but feed
His heart to this match to draw on th' other,
Wherein my joy sits with a full wish crown'd,
Only his mood excepted, which must change
By opposite policies, courses indirect:
Plain dealing in this world takes no effect.
This mad girl I'll acquaint with my intent,
Get her assistance, make my fortunes known:
'Twixt lovers' hearts, she's a fit instrument
And has the art to help them to their own
By her advice, for in that craft she's wise:
My love and I may meet, spite of all spies.

div.head: [III.i. Gray's Inn Fields]
div.stage: Enter Laxton in Gray's Inn Fields with the Coachman.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Coachman.

sp.speaker: COACHMAN
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: [Giving him money] There's a tester more. Prithee drive thy coach to the hither end of Marybone Park, a fit place for Moll to get in.

sp.speaker: COACHMAN
sp.p: Marybone Park, sir?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Ay, it's in our way, thou know'st.

sp.speaker: COACHMAN
sp.p: It shall be done, sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Coachman.

sp.speaker: COACHMAN
sp.p: Anon, sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Are we fitted with good [frampold] jades?

sp.speaker: COACHMAN
sp.p: The best in Smithfield, I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: May we safely take the upper hand of any [couch'd] velvet cap or tufftaffety jacket? For they keep a vild swaggering in coaches nowadays; the highways are stopp'd with them.

sp.speaker: COACHMAN
sp.p: My life for yours and baffle 'em too, sir. Why, they are the same jades, believe it, sir, that have drawn all your famous whores to Ware.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Nay then, they know their business; they need no more instructions.

sp.speaker: COACHMAN
sp.p: They're so us'd to such journeys, sir, I never use whip to 'em, for if they catch but the scent of a wench once, they run like devils. Exit Coachman with his whip.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Fine Cerberus: that rogue will have the start of a thousand ones, for whilst others trot afoot, he'll ride prancing to hell upon a coach-horse. Stay, 'tis now about the hour of her appointment, but yet I see her not.

Hark, what's this? One, two, three, three by the clock at Savoy: this is the hour, and Gray's Inn Fields the place. She swore she'd meet me. Ha, yonder's two Inns a' Court men with one wench, but that's not she; they walk toward Islington out of my way. I see none yet dress'd like her: I must look for a shag ruff, a frieze jerkin, a short sword, and safeguard, or I get none. Why, Moll, prithee make haste or the coachman will curse us anon.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: [Aside] Oh, here's my gentleman: if they would keep their days as well with their mercers as their hours with their harlots, no bankrout would give seven score pound for a sergeant's place, for would you know a catchpole rightly deriv'd, the corruption of a citizen is the generation of a sergeant! How his eye hawks for venery!--Come, are you ready, sir?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Ready for what, sir?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Do you ask that now, sir? Why was this meeting 'pointed?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I thought you mistook me, sir.
You seem to be some young barrister.
I have no suit in law; all my land's sold:
I praise heaven for't; 't has rid me of much trouble.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Then I must wake you, sir. Where stands the coach?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Who's this? Moll? Honest Moll?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: So young and purblind? You're an old wanton in your eyes, I see that.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Th' art admirably suited for the Three Pigeons at Brainford; I'll swear I knew thee not.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I'll swear you did not, but you shall know me now.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: No, not here, we shall be spied, i'faith; the coach is better, come.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Stay.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: What, wilt thou untruss a point, Moll? She puts off her cloak and draws.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Yes, here's the point that I untruss: 't has but one tag; 'twill serve tho' to tie up a rogue's tongue.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: There's the gold with which you hir'd your hackney.
[Attacking him] Here's her pace;
She racks hard, and perhaps your bones will feel it!
Ten angels of mine own I've put to thine;
Win 'em and wear 'em!

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Hold, Moll, Mistress Mary!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Draw or I'll serve an execution on thee
Shall lay thee up till doomsday!

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Draw upon a woman? Why, what dost mean, Moll?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: To teach thy base thoughts manners: th' art one of those
That thinks each woman thy fond, flexible whore
If she but cast a liberal eye upon thee;
Turn back her head, she's thine, or amongst company,
By chance drink first to thee. Then she's quite gone;
There's no means to help her, nay, for a need,
Wilt swear unto thy credulous fellow lechers
That th' art more in favour with a lady
At first sight than her monkey all her lifetime.
How many of our sex by such as thou
Have their good thoughts paid with a blasted name
That never deserved loosely, or did trip
In path of whoredom beyond cup and lip?
But for the stain of conscience and of soul,
Better had women fall into the hands
Of an act silent than a bragging nothing.
There's no mercy in't. What durst move you, sir,
To think me whorish, a name which I'd tear out
From the high German's throat if it lay ledger there
To dispatch privy slanders against me?
In thee I defy all men, their worst hates
And their best flatteries, all their golden witchcrafts
With which they entangle the poor spirits of fools,
Distressed needlewomen, and trade-fall'n wives.
Fish that must needs bite or themselves be bitten,
Such hungry things as these may soon be took
With a worm fast'ned on a golden hook:
Those are the lecher's food, his prey; he watches
For quarrelling wedlocks, and poor shifting sisters:
'Tis the best fish he takes. But why, good fisherman,
Am I thought meat for you, that never yet
Had angling rod cast towards me? 'Cause, you'll say,
I'm given to sport, I'm often merry, jest.
Had mirth no kindred in the world but lust?
Oh, shame take all her friends then! But howe'er
Thou and the baser world censure my life,
I'll send 'em word by thee, and write so much
Upon thy breast, 'cause thou shalt bear 't in mind:
Tell them 'twere base to yield where I have conquer'd.
I scorn to prostitute myself to a man,
I that can prostitute a man to me:
And so I greet thee.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Hear me!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Would the spirits
Of all my [slanderers] were clasp'd in thine
That I might vex an army at one time!

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I do repent me! Hold!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: You'll die the better Christian then.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I do confess I have wrong'd thee, Moll.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Confession is but poor amends for wrong,
Unless a rope would follow.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I ask thee pardon.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I'm your hir'd whore, sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I yield both purse and body!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Both are mine and now at my disposing.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Spare my life!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I scorn to strike thee basely.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Spoke like a noble girl, i'faith! [Aside] Heart, I think I fight with a familiar or the ghost of a fencer! Sh' has wounded me gallantly. Call you this a lecherous [voyage]? Here's blood would have serv'd me this seven year in broken heads and cut fingers, and it now runs all out together. Pox a' the Three Pigeons! I would the coach were here now to carry me to the chirurgeon's. Exit Laxton.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: If I could meet my enemies one by one thus,
I might make pretty shift with 'em in time
And make 'em know she that has wit and spirit
May scorn to live beholding to her body for meat
Or for apparel like your common dame
That makes shame get her clothes to cover shame.
Base is that mind that kneels unto her body,
As if a husband stood in awe on's wife:
My spirit shall be mistress of this house
As long as I have time in'l. Enter Trapdoor. [Aside] Oh,
Here comes my man that would be: 'tis his hour.
Faith, a good well-set fellow, if his spirit
Be answerable to his umbles. He walks stiff,
But whether he will stand to't stiffly, there's the point;
H'as a good calf for't, and ye shall have many a woman
Choose him she means to [make] her head by his calf.
I do not know their tricks in't. Faith, he seems
A man without; I'll try what he is within.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: [Aside] She told me Gray's Inn Fields 'twixt three and four.
I'll fit her mistress-ship with a piece of service!
I'm hir'd to rid the town of one mad girl. She justles him.
What a pox ails you, sir?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: [Aside] He begins like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Heart, is the field so narrow, or your eyesight?
Life, he comes back again!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Was this spoke to me, sir?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: I cannot tell, sir.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Go, y'are a coxcomb!

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Y'are a slave!

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: I hope there's law for you, sir.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: [Yea], do you see, sir? Turn his hat.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Heart, this is no good dealing!
Pray let me know what house you're of.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p:
One of the Temple, sir.
Fillips him.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Mass, so methinks!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: And yet sometime I lie
About Chick Lane.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: I like you the worse
Because you shift your lodging so often.
I'll not meddle with you for that trick, sir.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: A good shift, but it shall not serve your turn.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: You'll give me leave to pass about my business, sir?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Your business?
I'll make you wait on me before I ha' done,
And glad to serve me too.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: How, sir! Serve you?
Not if there were no more men in England!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: But if there were no more women in England,
I hope you'd wait upon your mistress then.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Mistress!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Oh, you're a tried spirit at a push, sir!

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: What would your worship have me do?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: You a fighter?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: No, I praise heaven; I had better grace and more manners.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: As how I pray, sir?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Life, 't had been a beastly part of me to have drawn my weapons upon my mistress! All the world would 'a' cried shame of me for that.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Why, but you knew me not.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Do not say so, mistress; I knew you by your wide straddle, as well as if I had been in your belly.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Well, we shall try you further; i' th' mean time we give you entertainment.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Thank your good mistress-ship.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: How many suits have you?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: No more suits than backs, mistress.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Well, if you deserve, I cast off this next week,
And you may creep into't.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Thank your good worship.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Come, follow me to St. Thomas Apostle's;
I'll put a livery cloak upon your back
The first thing I do.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: I follow, my dear mistress.

div.head: [III.ii. Gallipot's house]
div.stage: Enter Mistress Gallipot as from supper, her husband after her.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: What, Pru! Nay, sweet Prudence!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: What a pruing keep you; I think the baby would have a teat, it kyes so. Pray be not so fond of me: leave your city humours; I'm vex'd at you to see how like a calf you come bleating after me.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Nay, honey Pru. How does your rising up before all the table show? And flinging from my friends so uncivilly? Fie, Pru, fie, come!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Then up and ride, i'faith.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Up and ride? Nay, my pretty Pru, that's far from my thought, duck. Why, mouse, thy mind is nibbling at something. What is't? What lies upon thy stomach?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Such an ass as you. Hoyda, y'are best turn midwife or physician! Y'are a pothecary already, but I'm none of your drugs.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Thou art a sweet drug, sweet'st Pru, and the more thou art pounded, the more precious.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Must you be prying into a woman's secrets, say ye?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Woman's secrets?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: What, I cannot have a qualm come upon me but your teeth waters till your nose hang over it.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: It is my love, dear wife.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Your love? Your love is all words; give me deeds: I cannot abide a man that's too fond over me, so cookish; thou dost not know how to handle a woman in her kind.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: No, Pru? Why, I hope I have handled--

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Handle a fool's head of your own, fie, fie!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Ha, ha, 'tis such a wasp! It does me good now to have her [sting] me, little rogue.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Now fie, how you vex me! I cannot abide these [apron] husbands, such cotqueans: you overdo your things; they become you scurvily.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: [Aside] Upon my life, she breeds! Heaven knows how I have strain'd myself to please her, night and day. I wonder why we citizens should get children so fretful and untoward in the breeding, their fathers being for the most part as gentle as milch-kine.--Shall I leave thee, my Pru?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Thou shalt not be vex'd no more, pretty kind rogue: take no cold, sweet Pru. Exit Gallipot.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: As your wit has done. [Taking out a letter] Now, Master Laxton, show your head. What news from you? Would any husband suspect that a woman crying, "Buy any scurvygrass" should bring love letters amongst her herbs to his wife? Pretty trick, fine conveyance! Had jealousy a thousand eyes, a silly woman with scurvygrass blinds them all.
sp.l: Laxton, with bays
Crown I thy wit for this: it deserves praise.
This makes me affect thee more; this proves thee wise.
'Lack what poor shift is love forc'd to devise?
sp.p:
To th' point: She reads the letter.
"Oh, sweet creature,"--a sweet beginning--"pardon my long absence, for thou shalt shortly be possessed with my presence. Though Demophon was false to Phyllis, I will be to thee as Pan-da-rus was to Cres-sida; tho' Aeneas made an ass of Dido, I will die to thee ere I do so. Oh, sweet'st creature, make much of me, for no man beneath the silver moon shall make more of a woman than I do of thee. Furnish me therefore with thirty pounds; you must do it of necessity for me: I languish till I see some comfort come from thee, protesting not to die in thy debt, but rather to live so, as hitherto I have and will. Thy true Laxton ever."
sp.l: Alas, poor gentleman! Troth, I pity him.
How shall I raise this money? Thirty pound?
'Tis thirty sure, a 3 before an O;
I know his threes too well. My childbed linen?
Shall I pawn that for him? Then if my mark
Be known, I am undone; it may be thought
My husband's bankrout. Which way shall I turn?
Laxton, what with my own fears and thy wants,
I'm as a needle 'twixt two adamants.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Nay, nay, wife, the women are all up! [Aside] Ha! How, reading a' letters? I smell a goose, a couple of capons, and a gammon of bacon from her mother out of the country, I hold my life.--Steal, steal!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Oh, beshrew your heart!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: What letter's that?
I'll see't. She tears the letter.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Oh, would thou hadst no eyes to see
The downfall of me and thyself: I'm forever,
Forever I'm undone!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: What ails my Pru?
What paper's that thou tear'st?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Would I could tear
My very heart in pieces, for my soul
Lies on the rack of shame that tortures me
Beyond a woman's suffering.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Had you no other vengeance to throw down
But even in height of all my joys--

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Dear woman!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: When the full sea of pleasure and content
Seem'd to flow over me--

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: As thou desirest to keep
Me out of bedlam, tell what troubles thee?
Is not thy child at nurse fall'n sick, or dead?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Oh, no!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Heavens bless me! Are my barns and houses
Yonder at Hockley Hole consum'd with fire?
I can build more, sweet Pru.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: 'Tis worse, 'tis worse.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: My factor broke, or is the Jonas sunk?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Would all we had were swallowed in the waves,
Rather than both should be the scorn of slaves.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: I'm at my wits' end!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Oh, my dear husband,
Where once I thought myself a fixed star
Plac'd only in the heaven of thine arms,
I fear now I shall prove a wanderer.
Oh, Laxton, Laxton, is it then my fate
To be by thee o'erthrown?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Defend me, wisdom,
From falling into frenzy! On my knees,
Sweet Pru, speak: what's that Laxton who so heavy
Lies on thy bosom?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: I shall sure run mad!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: I shall run mad for company then. Speak to me:
I'm Gallipot thy husband. Pru, why, Pru!
Art sick in conscience for some villainous deed
Thou wert about to act? Didst mean to rob me?
Tush, I forgive thee! Hast thou on my bed
Thrust my soft pillow under another's head?
I'll wink at all faults, Pru; 'las, that's no more
Than what some neighbours near thee have done before.
Sweet honey Pru, what's that Laxton?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Out with him!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Oh, he's born to be my undoer!
This hand which thou call'st thine to him was given;
To him was I made sure i' th' sight of heaven.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: I never heard this thunder.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Yes, yes, before
I was to thee contracted, to him I swore,
Since last I saw him twelve months three times told
The moon hath drawn through her light silver bow,
For o'er the seas he went, and it was said,
But rumour lies, that he in France was dead.
But he's alive, oh, he's alive! He sent
That letter to me, which in rage I rent,
Swearing with oaths most damnably to have me,
Or tear me from this bosom. Oh, heavens save me!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: My heart will break! Sham'd and undone forever!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: So black a day poor wretch went o'er thee never.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: If thou shouldst wrastle with him at the law,
Th' art sure to fall: no odd sleight, no prevention.
I'll tell him th' art with child.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Umh.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Or give out
One of my men was ta'en a-bed with thee.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Umh, umh.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Before I lose thee, my dear Pru,
I'll drive it to that push.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Worse, and worse still:
You embrace a mischief to prevent an ill.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: I'll buy thee of him, stop his mouth with gold.
Think'st thou twill do?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Oh me, heavens grant it would!
Yet now my senses are set more in tune,
He writ, as I remember in his letter,
That he in riding up and down had spent
Ere he could find me thirty pounds: send that;
Stand not on thirty with him.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Forty, Pru;
Say thou the word 'tis done. We venture lives
For wealth, but must do more to keep our wives.
Thirty or forty, Pru?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Thirty, good sweet;
Of an ill bargain let's save what we can.
I'll pay it him with my tears: he was a man
When first I knew him of a meek spirit;
All goodness is not yet dried up, I hope.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: He shall have thirty pound; let that stop all:
Love's sweets taste best when we have drunk down gall.
sp.stage: Enter Master Tiltyard and his wife, Master Goshawk, and Mistress Openwork.
sp.l: God-so, our friends! Come, come, smooth your cheek;
After a storm the face of heaven looks sleek.

sp.speaker: TILTYARD
sp.p: Did I not tell you these turtles were together?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS TILTYARD
sp.p: How dost thou, sirrah? Why, sister Gallipot!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Lord, how she's chang'd!

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Is your wife ill, sir?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Yes, indeed la, sir, very ill, very ill, never worse!
