sp.speaker: MISTRESS TILTYARD
sp.p: How her head burns! Feel how her pulses work.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Sister, lie down a little; that always does me good.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS TILTYARD
sp.p: In good sadness, I find best ease in that too.
Has she laid some hot thing to her stomach?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: No, but I will lay something anon.

sp.speaker: TILTYARD
sp.p: Come, come, fools, you trouble her. Shall's go, Master Goshawk?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Yes, sweet Master Tiltyard. [Taking Mistress Openwork aside] Sirrah Rosamond, I hold my life Gallipot hath vex'd his wife.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: She has a horrible high colour indeed.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: We shall have your face painted with the same red soon at night when your husband comes from his rubbers in a false alley; thou wilt not believe me that his bowls run with a wrong bias.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: It cannot sink into me that he feeds upon stale mutton abroad, having better and fresher at home.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: What if I bring thee where thou shalt see him stand at rack and manger?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: I'll saddle him in's kind and spur him till he kick again.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Shall thou and I ride our journey then?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Here's my hand.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: No more.--Come, Master Tiltyard, shall we leap into the stirrups with our women and amble home?

sp.speaker: TILTYARD
sp.p: Yes, yes; come, wife.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS TILTYARD
sp.p: In troth, sister, I hope you will do well for all this.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: I hope I shall. Farewell, good sister, sweet Master Goshawk.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Welcome, brother, most kindly welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.p: Thanks, sir, for our good cheer. Exeunt all but Gallipot and his wife.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: It shall be so, because a crafty knave
Shall not outreach me nor walk by my door
With my wife arm in arm, as 'twere his whore,
I'll give him a golden coxcomb, thirty pound.
Tush, Pru, what's thirty pound? Sweet duck, look cheerly.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Thou art worthy of my heart: thou buy'st it dearly. Enter Laxton muffled.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: 'Ud's light, the tide's against me! A pox of your pothecaryship! Oh, for some glister to set him going! 'Tis one of Hercules' labours to tread one of these city hens because their cocks are still crowing over them; there's no turning tail here, I must on.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Oh, husband, see, he comes!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Let me deal with him.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Bless you, sir.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.p: Be you bless'd too, sir, if you come in peace.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Have you any good pudding tobacco, sir?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Oh, pick no quarrels, gentle sir! My husband
Is not a man of weapon as you are;
He knows all: I have op'ned all before him
Concerning you.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Zounds, has she shown my letters!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Suppose my case were yours, what would you do
At such a pinch, such batteries, such assaults
Of father, mother, kindred, to dissolve
The knot you tied, and to be bound to him?
How could you shift this storm off?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: If I know, hang me.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Besides a story of your death was read
Each minute to me.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: [Aside] What a pox means this riddling?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Be wise, sir; let not you and I be toss'd
On lawyers' pens: they have sharp nibs and draw
Men's very heart-blood from them. What need you, sir,
To beat the drum of my wife's infamy,
And call your friends together, sir, to prove
Your [precontract] when sh' has confess'd it?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Umh, sir,
Has she confess'd it?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Sh' has, faith, to me, sir,
Upon your letter sending.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: I have, I have.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: [Aside] If I let this iron cool, call me slave.--
Do you hear, you dame Prudence? Think'st thou, vile woman,
I'll take these blows and wink?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Upon my knees--

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Out, impudence!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Good sir--

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: You goatish slaves,
No wild fowl to cut up but mine?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Alas, sir,
You make her flesh to tremble; fright her not.
She shall do reason and what's fit.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: I'll have thee,
Wert thou more common than an hospital
And more diseased.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: But one word, good sir.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: So, sir?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: I married her, have [lain] with her, and got
Two children on her body; think but on that.
Have you so beggarly an appetite,
When I upon a dainty dish have fed,
To dine upon my scraps, my leavings? Ha, sir?
Do I come near you [now], sir?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Be-Lady, you touch me.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Would not you scorn to wear my clothes, sir?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Right, sir.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Then pray, sir, wear not her, for she's a garment
So fitting for my body, I'm loath
Another should put it on; you will undo both.
Your letter, as she said, complain'd you had spent
In quest of her some thirty pound: I'll pay it.
Shall that, sir, stop this gap up 'twixt you two?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Well, if I swallow this wrong, let her thank you;
The money being paid, sir, I am gone.
Farewell, oh women! Happy's he trusts none.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Dispatch him hence, sweet husband.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Yes, dear wife.
Pray, sir, come in. Ere Master Laxton part
Thou shalt in wine drink to him.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: With all my heart.
[Aside to Laxton] How dost thou like my wit?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: [Aside to Mistress Gallipot] Rarely!
sp.stage: Exit Master Gallipot and his wife.
sp.l: That wile
By which the serpent did the first woman beguile
Did ever since all women's bosoms fill;
Y'are apple-eaters all, deceivers still.

div.head: [III.iii. Holborn Street]
div.stage: Enter Sir Alexander Wengrave, Sir Davy Dapper, Sir Adam Appleton at one door, and Trapdoor at another door.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Out with your tale, Sir Davy, to Sir Adam;
A knave is in mine eye deep in my debt.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Nay, if he be a knave, sir, hold him fast.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Speak softly. What egg is there hatching now?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: A duck's egg, sir, a duck that has eaten a frog; I have crack'd the shell and some villainy or other will peep out presently. The duck that sits is the bouncing ramp, that roaring girl my mistress, the drake that must tread is your son Sebastian.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Be quick.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: As the tongue of an oyster-wench.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: And see thy news be true.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: As a barber's every Saturday night. Mad Moll--

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Ah.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Must be let in without knocking at your back gate.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Your chamber will be made bawdy.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: She comes in a shirt of mail.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: How shirt of mail?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Yes, sir, or a male shirt, that's to say in man's apparel.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: To my son?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Close to your son: your son and her moon will be in conjunction, if all almanacs lie not. Her black safeguard is turn'd into a deep slop, the holes of her upper body to button holes, her waistcoat to a doublet, her placket to the ancient seat of a codpiece, and you shall take 'em both with standing collars.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Art sure of this?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: As every throng is sure of a pickpocket, as sure as a whore is of the clients all Michaelmas Term, and of the pox after the term.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: The time of their tilting?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Three.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: The day?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: This.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Away, ply it, watch her.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: As the devil doth for the death of a bawd, I'll watch her; do you catch her.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: She's fast: here weave thou the nets. Hark--

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: They are made.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I told them thou didst owe me money; hold it up, maintain 't.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Stiffly, as a puritan does contention. [Loudly] [Pox], I owe thee not the value of a halfpenny halter!

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Thou shalt be hang'd in't ere thou scape so! Varlet, I'll make thee look through a grate.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: I'll do't presently, through a tavern grate. Drawer! Pish! Exit Trapdoor.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Has the knave vex'd you, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Ask'd him my money;
He swears my son receiv'd it. Oh, that boy
Will ne'er leave heaping sorrows on my heart
Till he has broke it quite.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Is he still wild?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: As is a Russian bear.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: But he has left
His old haunt with that baggage?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Worse still and worse:
He lays on me his shame, I on him my curse.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: My son Jack Dapper then shall run with him,
All in one pasture.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Proves your son bad too, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: As villainy can make him. Your Sebastian
Dotes but on one drab, mine on a thousand,
A noise of fiddlers, tobacco, wine and a whore,
A mercer that will let him take up more,
Dice, and a water-spaniel with a duck: oh,
Bring him a-bed with these! When his purse jingles,
Roaring boys follow at's tale, fencers and ningles,
Beasts Adam ne'er gave name to: these horse-leeches suck
My son; he being drawn dry, they all live on smoke.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Tobacco?

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Right, but I have in my brain
A windmill going that shall grind to dust
The follies of my son, and make him wise
Or a stark fool; pray lend me your advise.

sp.speaker: [SIR ALEXANDER, SIR ADAM]
sp.l: That shall you, good Sir Davy.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Here's the springe
I ha' set to catch this woodcock in: an action
In a false name, unknown to him, is ent'red
I' th' counter to arrest Jack Dapper.

sp.speaker: [SIR ALEXANDER, SIR ADAM]
sp.l: Ha, ha, he!

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Think you the counter cannot break him?

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Break him?
Yes, and break's heart too if he lie there long.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: I'll make him sing a countertenor sure.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: No way to tame him like it; there he shall learn
What money is indeed, and how to spend it.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: He's bridled there.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Ay, yet knows not how to mend it.
Bedlam cures not more madmen in a year
Than one of the counters does; men pay more dear
There for their wit than anywhere; a counter:
Why, 'tis an university! Who not sees?
As scholars there, so here men take degrees
And follow the same studies all alike.
Scholars learn first logic and rhetoric.
So does a prisoner: with fine honey'd speech
At's first coming in he doth persuade, beseech,
He may be lodg'd with one that is not itchy,
To lie in a clean chamber, in sheets not lousy;
But when he has no money, then does he try
By subtle logic and quaint sophistry
To make the keepers trust him.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Say they do?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Then he's a graduate.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Say they trust him not?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Then is he held a freshman and a sot,
And never shall commence, but being still barr'd
Be expuls'd from the master's side to th' twopenny ward,
Or else i' th' hole be plac'd.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: When then I pray
Proceeds a prisoner?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: When money being the aim
He can dispute with his hard creditors' hearts
And get out clear, he's then a Master of Arts.
Sir Davy, send your son to Wood Street College:
A gentleman can nowhere get more knowledge.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: There gallants study hard.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: True, to get money.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Lies by th' heels, i'faith; thanks, thanks. I ha' sent
For a couple of bears shall paw him. Enter Sergeant Curtilax and Yeoman Hanger.

sp.speaker: SIR ADAM
sp.l: Who comes yonder?

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: They look like puttocks; these should be they.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I know 'em;
They are officers, sir. We'll leave you.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: My good knights.
Leave me; you see I'm haunted now with spirits.

sp.speaker: [SIR ALEXANDER, SIR ADAM]
sp.l: Fare you well, sir. Exeunt [Sir] Alexander and [Sir] Adam.

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.l: [Aside to Hanger] This old muzzle-chops should be he by the fellow's description.--Save you, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Come hither, you mad varlets. Did not my man tell you I watch'd here for you?

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.l: One in a blue coat, sir, told us that in this place an old gentleman would watch for us, a thing contrary to our oath, for we are to watch for every wicked member in a city.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: You'll watch then for ten thousand. What's thy name, honesty?

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.l: Sergeant Curtilax I, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: An excellent name for a sergeant, Curtilax.
Sergeants indeed are weapons of the law
When prodigal ruffians far in debt are grown:
Should not you cut them, citizens were o'erthrown.
Thou dwell'st hereby in Holborn, Curtilax?

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.l: That's my circuit, sir; I conjure most in that circle.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: And what young toward whelp is this?

sp.speaker: HANGER
sp.l: Of the same litter: his yeoman, sir; my name's Hanger.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.l: Yeoman Hanger.
One pair of shears sure cut out both your coats:
You have two names most dangerous to men's throats;
You two are villainous loads on gentlemen's backs.
Dear ware, this Hanger and this Curtilax.

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: We are as other men are, sir. I cannot see but he who makes a show of honesty and religion, if his claws can fasten to his liking, he draws blood. All that live in the world are but great fish and little fish, and feed upon one another: some eat up whole men; a sergeant cares but for the shoulder of a man. They call us knaves and curs, but many times he that sets us on worries more lambs one year than we do in seven.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: Spoke like a noble Cerberus. Is the action ent'red?

sp.speaker: HANGER
sp.p: His name is ent'red in the book of unbelievers.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: What book's that?

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: The book where all prisoners' names stand, and not one amongst forty when he comes in believes to come out in haste.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: Be as dogged to him as your office allows you to be.

sp.speaker: [CURTILAX, HANGER]
sp.p: Oh, sir!

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: You know the unthrift Jack Dapper?

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: Ay, ay, sir. That gull? As well as I know my yeoman.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: And you know his father too, Sir Davy Dapper?

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: As damn'd a usurer as ever was among Jews; if he were sure his father's skin would yield him any money, he would when he dies [flay] it off, and sell it to cover drums for children at Bartholomew Fair.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: [Aside] What toads are these to spit poison on a man to his face!--Do you see, my honest rascals? Yonder greyhound is the dog he hunts with: out of that tavern Jack Dapper will sally. Sa, sa; give the counter, on, set upon him.

sp.speaker: [CURTILAX, HANGER]
sp.p: We'll charge him upo' th' back, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: Take no bail, put mace enough into his caudle, double your files, traverse your ground.

sp.speaker: [CURTILAX, HANGER]
sp.p: Brave, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: Cry arm, arm, arm.

sp.speaker: [CURTILAX, HANGER]
sp.p: Thus, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR DAVY
sp.p: There boy, there boy, away: look to your prey, my true English wolves, and so I vanish. Exit Sir Davy.

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: Some warden of the sergeants begat this old fellow, upon my life! Stand close.

sp.speaker: HANGER
sp.p: Shall the ambuscado lie in one place?

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: No, [nook] thou yonder. Enter Moll and Trapdoor.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Ralph.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: What says my brave captain male and female?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: This Holborn is such a wrangling street.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: That's because lawyers walks to and fro in't.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Here's such justling, as if everyone we met were drunk and reel'd.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Stand, mistress: do you not smell carrion?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Carrion? No, yet I spy ravens.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Some poor wind-shaken gallant will anon fall into sore labour, and these men-midwives must bring him to bed i' the counter: there all those that are great with child with debts lie in.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Stand up.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Like your new maypole.

sp.speaker: HANGER
sp.p: Whist, whew.

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: Hump, no.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Peeping? It shall go hard, huntsmen, but I'll spoil your game. They look for all the world like two infected maltmen coming muffled up in their cloaks in a frosty morning to London.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: A course, captain; a bear comes to the stake. Enter Jack Dapper and Gull.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: It should be so, for the dogs struggle to be let loose.

sp.speaker: HANGER
sp.p: Whew.

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: Hemp.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Hark, Trapdoor, follow your leader.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Gull.

sp.speaker: GULL
sp.p: Master.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Didst ever see such an ass as I am, boy?

sp.speaker: GULL
sp.p: No, by my troth, sir. To lose all your money, yet have false dice of your own! Why, 'tis as I saw a great fellow used t'other day: he had a fair sword and buckler, and yet a butcher dry-beat him with a cudgel.
Honest sergeant--

sp.speaker: [TRAPDOOR]
sp.p: Fly, fly, Master Dapper: you'll be arrested else!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Run, Gull, and draw!

sp.speaker: GULL
sp.p: Run, master, Gull follows you! [Exeunt Jack] Dapper and Gull.

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: I know you well enough: you're but a whore to hang upon any man.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Whores then are like sergeants, so now hang you! [To Trapdoor] Draw, rogue, but strike not: for a broken pate they'll keep their beds and recover twenty marks damages.

sp.speaker: CURTILAX
sp.p: You shall pay for this rescue! [To Hanger] Run down Shoe Lane and meet him. [Exeunt Curtilax and Hanger.]

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Shoo! Is this a rescue, gentlemen, or no?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Rescue? A pox on 'em! Trapdoor, let's away;
I'm glad I have done perfect one good work today.
If any gentleman be in scriveners' bands,
Send but for Moll, she'll bail him by these hands.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Unhappy in the follies of a son,
Led against judgment, sense, obedience,
And all the powers of nobleness and wit:
Oh, wretched father!
Now, Trapdoor, will she come?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: In man's apparel, sir; I am in her heart now
And share in all her secrets.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Peace, peace, peace.
Here, take my German watch; hang 't up in sight
That I may see her hang in English for't.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: I warrant you for that now; next sessions rids her, sir: this watch will bring her in better than a hundred constables.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Good Trapdoor, sayst thou so? Thou cheer'st my heart
After a storm of sorrow. My gold chain too:
Here, take a hundred marks in yellow links.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: That will do well to bring the watch to light, sir,
And worth a thousand of your headboroughs' lanthorns.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Place that a' the court cupboard, let it lie
Full in the view of her thief-whorish eye.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: She cannot miss it, sir; I see't so plain
That I could steal 't myself.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Perhaps thou shalt too,
That or something as weighty; what she leaves,
Thou shalt come closely in and filch away,
And all the weight upon her back I'll lay.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: You cannot assure that, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: No, what lets it?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Being a stout girl, perhaps she'll desire pressing,
Then all the weight must lie upon her belly.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Belly or back I care not so I've one.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: You're of my mind for that, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Hang up my ruff band with the diamond at it;
It may be she'll like that best.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: [Aside] It's well for her that she must have her choice; he thinks nothing too good for her.--If you hold on this mind a little longer, it shall be the first work I do to turn thief myself; would do a man good to be hang'd when he is so well provided for.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: So, well said; all hangs well, would she hung so too:
The sight would please me more than all their [glisterings].
Oh, that my mysteries to such straits should run
That I must rob myself to bless my son! Exeunt. Enter Sebastian, with Mary Fitzallard like a page, and Moll [in man's clothing].

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Thou hast done me a kind office, without touch
Either of sin or shame; our loves are honest.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: I'd scorn to make such shift to bring you together else.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Now have I time and opportunity
Without all fear to bid thee welcome, love. Kiss.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: Never with more desire and harder venture.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: How strange this shows, one man to kiss another.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I'd kiss such men to choose, Moll;
Methinks a woman's lip tastes well in a doublet.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Many an old madam has the better fortune then,
Whose breaths grew stale before the fashion came;
If that will help 'em, as you think 'twill do,
They'll learn in time to pluck on the hose too.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: The older they wax, Moll--troth, I speak seriously--
As some have a conceit their drink tastes better
In an outlandish cup than in our own,
So methinks every kiss she gives me now
In this strange form is worth a pair of two.
Here we are safe and furthest from the eye
Of all suspicion: this is my [father's] chamber,
Upon which floor he never steps till night;
Here he mistrusts me not, nor I his coming.
At mine own chamber he still pries unto me;
My freedom is not there at mine own finding,
Still check'd and curb'd: here he shall miss his purpose.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: And what's your business now you have your mind, sir?
At your great suit I promis'd you to come;
I pitied her for name's sake, that a Moll
Should be so cross'd in love when there's so many
That owes nine lays apiece, and not so little.
My tailor fitted her. How like you his work?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: So well no art can mend it for this purpose,
But to thy wit and help we're chief in debt
And must live still beholding.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Any honest pity
I'm willing to bestow upon poor ring-doves.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I'll offer no worse play.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Nay, and you should, sir;
I should draw first and prove the quicker man.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Hold, there shall need no weapon at this meeting;
But 'cause thou shalt not loose thy fury idle,
Here take this viol, run upon the guts,
And end thy quarrel singing.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Like a swan above bridge,
For look you here's the bridge, and here am I.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Hold on, sweet Moll.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: I've heard her much commended, sir, for one that was ne'er taught.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: I'm much beholding to 'em. Well, since you'll needs put us together, sir, I'll play my part as well as I can; it shall ne'er be said I came into a gentleman's chamber and let his instrument hang by the walls.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Why, well said, Moll! I'faith, it had been a shame for that gentleman then that would have let it hung still and ne'er off'red thee it.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: There it should have been still then for Moll, for though the world judge impudently of me, I ne'er came into that chamber yet where I took down the instrument myself.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Pish, let 'em prate abroad; th' art here where thou art known and lov'd. There be a thousand close dames that will call the viol an unmannerly instrument for a woman and therefore talk broadly of thee, when you shall have them sit wider to a worse quality.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Push, I ever fall asleep and think not of 'em, sir, and thus I dream.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Prithee let's hear thy dream, Moll.

sp.speaker: MOLL.
sp.l: I dream there is a mistress,
And she lays out the money;
She goes unto her sisters,
She never comes at any.
She says she went to th' Burse for patterns;
You shall find her at Saint Kathern's,
And comes home with never a penny

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: That's a free mistress, faith.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Ay, ay, ay, like her that sings it, one of thine own choosing.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: But shall I dream again?
Here comes a wench will brave ye,
Her courage was so great:
She lay with one o' the navy,
Her husband lying i' the Fleet,
Yet oft with him she cavill'd.
I wonder what she ails.
Her husband's ship lay gravell'd,
When hers could hoise up sails;
Yet she began like all my foes
To call whore first, for so do those:
A pox of all false tails!

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Marry, amen say I.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] So say I too.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Hang up the viol now, sir: all this while I was in a dream; one shall lie rudely then, but being awake, I keep my legs together. A watch: what's a' clock here?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Now, now, she's trapp'd.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Between one and two; nay, then I care not. A watch and a musician are cousin-germans in one thing: they must both keep time well, or there's no goodness in 'em; the one else deserves to be dash'd against a wall, and t'other to have his brains knock'd out with a fiddle case. What? A loose chain and a dangling diamond.
Here were a brave booty for an evening-thief now;
There's many a younger brother would be glad
To look twice in at a window for't,
And wriggle in and out, like an eel in a sandbag.
Oh, if men's secret youthful faults should judge 'em,
'Twould be the general'st execution
That e'er was seen in England;
There would be but few left to sing the ballets.
There would be so much work: most of our brokers
Would be chosen for hangmen, a good day for them;
They might renew their wardropes of free cost then.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: This is the roaring wench must do us good.

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.l: No poison, sir, but serves us for some use,
Which is confirm'd in her.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Peace, peace!
Foot, I did hear him sure, where'er he be!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Who did you hear?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: My father.
'Twas like a sight of his; I must be wary.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] No, wilt not be. Am I alone so wretched
That nothing takes? I'll put him to his plunge for't.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Life, here he comes! [To Moll, giving her money] Sir, I beseech you take it;
Your way of teaching does so much content me,
I'll make it four pound. Here's forty shillings, sir.
I think I name it right. [Aside to her] Help me, good Moll.--
Forty in hand.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Sir, you shall pardon me;
I have more of the mean'st scholar I can teach.
This pays me more than you have off'red yet.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: At the next quarter
When I receive the means my father 'lows me,
You shall have t'other forty.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] This were well now,
Were 't to a man whose sorrows had blind eyes,
But mine behold his follies and untruths
With two clear glasses.--How now?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: What's he there?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: You're come in good time, sir: I've a suit to you;
I'd crave your present kindness.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: What is he there?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: A gentleman, a musician, sir, one of excellent fing'ring.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Ay, I think so; I wonder how they scap'd her.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: H'as the most delicate stroke, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] A stroke indeed: I feel it at my heart.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Puts down all your famous musicians.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Ay, a whore may put down a hundred of 'em.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Forty shillings is the agreement, sir, between us.
Now, sir, my present means mounts but to half on't.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: And he stands upon the whole.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Ay, indeed does he, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] And will do still; he'll ne'er be in other tale.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Therefore I'd stop his mouth, sir, and I could.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Hum, true, there is no other way indeed.
[Aside] His folly hardens; shame must needs succeed.--
Now, sir, I understand you profess music.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: I am a poor servant to that liberal science, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Where is it you teach?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Right against Clifford's Inn.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Hum, that's a fit place for it. You have many scholars?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: And some of worth whom I may call my masters.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Ay, true, a company of whoremasters.--
You teach to sing too?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Marry, do I, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I think you'll find an apt scholar of my son,
Especially for prick-song.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: I have much hope of him.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] I am sorry for't; I have the less for that.--
You can play any lesson?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: At first sight, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: There's a thing called "The Witch." Can you play that?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: I would be sorry anyone should mend me in't.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Ay, I believe thee: thou hast so bewitch'd my son,
No care will mend the work that thou hast done.
I have bethought myself, since my art fails,
I'll make her policy the art to trap her.
Here are four angels mark'd with holes in them,
Fit for his crack'd companions; gold he will give her:
These will I make induction to her ruin
And rid shame from my house, grief from my heart.--
Here, son, in what you take content and pleasure,
Want shall not curb you. [Giving him money] Pay the gentleman
His latter half in gold.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: [Aside] Oh, may the operation an't end three:
In her, life, shame in him, and grief in me. Exit [Sir] Alexander.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Faith, thou shalt have 'em: 'tis my father's gift.
Never was man beguil'd with better shift.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: He that can take me for a male musician,
I cannot choose but make him my instrument
And play upon him.

div.head: [IV.ii. Openwork's house]
div.stage: Enter Mistress Gallipot and Mistress Openwork.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Is then that bird of yours, Master Goshawk, so wild?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: A goshawk, a puttock: all for prey; he angles for fish, but he loves flesh better.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Is't possible his smooth face should have wrinkles in't and we not see them?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Possible! Why, have not many handsome legs in silk stockings villainous splay feet for all their great roses?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Troth, sirrah, thou sayst true.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Didst never see an archer as thou 'ast walk'd by Bunhill look a-squint when he drew his bow?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Yes, when his arrows have fline toward Islington, his eyes have shot clean contrary towards Pimlico.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: For all the world so does Master Goshawk double with me.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Oh, fie upon him! If he double once, he's not for me.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Because Goshawk goes in a shag-ruff band, with a face sticking up in't which shows like an agate set in a cramp-ring, he thinks I'm in love with him.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: 'Las, I think he takes his mark amiss in thee.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: He has by often beating into me made me believe that my husband kept a whore.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Swore to me that my husband this very morning went in a boat with a tilt over it to the Three Pigeons at Brainford, and his punk with him under his tilt.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: That were wholesome.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: I believ'd it, fell a-swearing at him, cursing of harlots, made me ready to hoise up sail, and be there as soon as he.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: So, so.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: And for that voyage Goshawk comes hither incontinently. But, sirrah, this water-spaniel dives after no duck but me; his hope is having me at Brainford to make me cry quack.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Art sure of it?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Sure of it! My poor innocent Openwork came in as I was poking my ruff; presently hit I him i' the teeth with the Three Pigeons: he forswore all, I up and opened all, and now stands he in a shop hard by like a musket on a rest, to hit Goshawk i' the eye when he comes to fetch me to the boat.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Such another lame gelding offered to carry me through thick and thin--Laxton, sirrah--but I am rid of him now.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Happy is the woman can be rid of 'em all. 'Las, what are your whisking gallants to our husbands, weigh 'em rightly man for man?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Troth, mere shallow things.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Idle simple things, running heads, and yet let 'em run over us never so fast, we shopkeepers, when all's done, are sure to have 'em in our purse-nets at length, and when they are in, Lord, what simple animals they are!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Then they hang the head.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Then they droop.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Then they write letters.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Then they cog.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Then they deal underhand with us, and we must ingle with our husbands a-bed, and we must swear they are our cousins, and able to do us a pleasure at court.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: And yet when we have done our best, all's but put into a riven dish: we are but frump'd at and libell'd upon.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Oh, if it were the good Lord's will, there were a law made no citizen should trust any of 'em at all! Enter Goshawk.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: [Aside to Mistress Openwork] Hush, sirrah, Goshawk flutters.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: How now, are you ready?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Nay, are you ready? A little thing, you see, makes us ready.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Us? Why, must she make one i' the voyage?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Oh, by any means. Do I know how my husband will handle me?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: [Aside] Foot, how shall I find water to keep these two mills going?--Well, since you'll needs be clapp'd under hatches, if I sail not with you both till all split, hang me up at the mainyard and duck me. [Aside] It's but liquoring them both soundly, and then you shall see their cork heels fly up high, like two swans when their tails are above water and their long necks under water, diving to catch gudgeons.--Come, come, oars stand ready, the tide's with us: on with those false faces. Blow winds and thou shalt take thy husband casting out his net to catch fresh salmon at Brainford.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: I believe you'll eat of a cod's head of your own dressing before you reach half way thither. [The women don masks.]

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: So, so, follow close; pin as you go. Enter Laxton muffled.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Do you hear?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Yes, I thank my ears.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I must have a bout with your pothecaryship.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: At what weapon?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: I must speak with you.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: No? You shall.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: Shall? Away, sous'd sturgeon, half fish, half flesh!

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: Faith, gib, are you spitting? I'll cut your tail, pusscat, for this.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: 'Las, poor Laxton, I think thy tail's cut already. Your worst!

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.p: If I do not-- Exit Laxton.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: Come, ha' you done?
[Aside to her] 'Sfoot, Rosamond, your husband!

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: How now? Sweet Master Goshawk, none more welcome;
I have wanted your embracements: when friends meet,
The music of the spheres sounds not more sweet
Than does their conference. Who is this? Rosamond?
Wife? How now, sister?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: [Aside to Mistress Openwork] Silence if you love me.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: Why mask'd?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Does a mask grieve you, sir?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.p: It does.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.p: Then y'are best get you a-mumming.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.p: [Aside to her] 'Sfoot, you'll spoil all!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.p: May not we cover our bare faces with masks
As well as you cover your bald heads with hats?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: No masks. Why, th' are thieves to beauty, that rob eyes
Of admiration in which true love lies.
Why are masks worn? Why good, or why desired,
Unless by their gay covers wits are fired
To read the vild'st looks? Many bad faces,
Because rich gems are treasured up in cases,
Pass by their privilege current, but as caves
Dam misers' gold, so masks are beauty's graves.
Men ne'er meet women with such muffled eyes
But they curse her that first did masks devise,
And swear it was some beldam. Come, off with 't.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Good faces mask'd are jewels kept by [sprites].
Hide none but bad ones, for they poison men's sights:
Show [them] as shopkeepers do their broid'red stuff,
By owl-light; fine wares cannot be open enough.
Prithee, sweet Rose, come strike this sail.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Sail?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Ha?
Yes, wife, strike sail, for storms are in thine eyes.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Th' are here, sir, in my brows if any rise.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Ha, brows? What says she, friend? Pray tell me why
Your two flags were advanc'd. The comedy,
Come, what's the comedy?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: 'Tis Westward Ho she says.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Are you both mad?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Is't market day at Brainford, and your ware
Not sent up yet?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: What market day? What ware?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: A pie with three pigeons in't; 'tis drawn and stays
Your cutting up.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: [Aside to her] As you regard my credit--

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Art mad?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Yes, lecherous goat, baboon!

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Baboon? Then toss
Me in a blanket.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Do I it well?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Rarely.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Belike, sir, she's not well; best leave her.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: No,
I'll stand the storm now how fierce so e'er it blow.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Did I for this lose all my friends? Refuse
Rich hopes and golden fortunes to be made
A stale to a common whore?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: This does amaze me!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Oh God, oh God, feed at reversion now?
A strumpet's leaving?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Rosamond--

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: [Aside] I sweat!
Would I lay in Cold Harbour!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Thou hast struck ten thousand daggers through my heart!

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Not I, by heaven, sweet wife.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Go, devil, go;
That which thou swear'st by damns thee.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: [Aside to her] 'Sheart, will you undo me?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Why stay you here? The star by which you sail
Shines yonder above Chelsea; you lose your shore
If this moon light you: seek out your light whore.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Ha?
Push! Your western [pug]--

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: [Aside] Zounds, now hell roars!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: With whom you tilted in a pair of oars
This very morning.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Oars?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: At Brainford, sir.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Rack not my patience. Master Goshawk,
Some slave has buzzed this into her, has he not?
I run atilt in Brainford with a woman?
'Tis a lie!
What old bawd tells thee this? 'Sdeath, 'tis a lie!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: 'Tis one to thy face shall justify all that I speak.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: 'Ud's soul, do but name that rascal!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: No, sir, I will not.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: [Aside] Keep thee there girl, then!
Sister, know you this varlet?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Swear true:
Is there a rogue so low damn'd? A second Judas?
A common hangman? Cutting a man's throat?
Does it to his face? Bite me behind my back?
A cur dog? Swear if you know this hell-hound!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: In truth I do.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Not for the world,
To have you to stab him.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: [Aside] Oh, brave girls: worth gold!

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: A word, honest Master Goshawk. Draw out his sword.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: What do you mean, sir?

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Keep off, and if the devil can give a name
To this new fury, holla it through my ear,
Or wrap it up in some hid character.

l.ref: I'll ride to Oxford and watch out mine eyes,

sp.l: But I'll hear the brazen head speak; or else
Show me but one hair of his head or beard,
That I may sample it. If the fiend I meet
In mine own house, I'll kill him, [in] the street,
Or at the church door: there, 'cause he seeks to untie
The knot God fastens, he deserves to die.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: My husband titles him.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Master Goshawk, pray, sir,
Swear to me that you know him or know him not.
Who makes me at Brainford to take up a petticoat
Beside my wife's?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: By heaven that man I know not!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Come, come, you lie.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: [Aside to her] Will you not have all out?
By heaven I know no man beneath the moon
Should do you wrong, but if I had his name,
I'd print it in text letters.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Print thine own then:
Didst not thou swear to me he kept his whore?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: And that in sinful Brainford they would commit
That which our lips did water at, sir, ha?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Thou spider, that hast woven thy cunning web
In mine own house t' ensnare me! Hast not thou
Suck'd nourishment even underneath this roof
And turn'd it all to poison? Spitting it
On thy friend's face, my husband, he as 'twere sleeping?
Only to leave him ugly to mine eyes
That they might glance on thee?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Speak: are these lies?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Mine own shame me confounds.
No more; he's stung.
Who'd think that in one body there could dwell
Deformity and beauty, heaven and hell?
Goodness I see is but outside: we all set
In rings of gold stones that be [counterfeit].
I thought you none.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Truth, I do.
This blemish grows in nature not in you,
For man's creation stick[s] even moles in scorn
On fairest cheeks. Wife, nothing is perfect born.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: I thought you had been born perfect.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: What's this whole world but a gilt, rotten pill?
For at the heart lies the old chore still.
I'll tell you, Master Goshawk, in your eye
I have seen wanton fire, and then to try
The soundness of my judgment, I told you
I kept a whore, made you believe 'twas true,
Only to feel how your pulse beat, but find
The world can hardly yield a perfect friend.
Come, come, a trick of youth, and 'tis forgiven;
This rub put by, our love shall run more even.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: You'll deal upon men's wives no more?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: No, you teach me
A trick for that.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: Troth, do not, they'll o'erreach thee.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Make my house yours, sir, still.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: I say you shall:
Seeing thus besieg'd it holds out, 'twill never fall. Enter Master Gallipot, and Greenwit like a sumner, Laxton muffled aloof off.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: With me, sir?

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: You, sir. I have gone snaffling up and down by your door this hour to watch for you.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: What's the matter, husband?

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: I have caught a cold in my head, sir, by sitting up late in the Rose Tavern, but I hope you understand my speech.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: So, sir.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: I cite you by the name of Hippocrates Gallipot, and you by the name of Prudence Gallipot, to appear upon Crastino, do you see, Crastino sancti Dunstani this Easter Term in Bow Church.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Where sir? What says he?

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Bow, Bow Church, to answer to a libel of precontract on the part and behalf of the said Prudence and another. Y'are best, sir, take a copy of the citation; 'tis but twelvepence.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: A citation?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: You pocky-nosed rascal, what slave fees you to this?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Slave? I ha' nothing to do with you, do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Laxton, is't not? What fagary is this?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Trust me, I thought, sir, this storm long ago
Had been full laid when, if you be rememb'red,
I paid you the last fifteen pound, besides
The thirty you had first, for then you swore.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Tush, tush, sir, oaths!
Truth, yet I'm loath to vex you, tell you what:
Make up the money I had an hundred pound
And take your belly full of her.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: An hundred pound?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: What, a hundred pound? He gets none: what, a hundred pound!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Sweet Pru, be calm, the gentleman offers thus,
If I will make the moneys that are past
A hundred pound, he will discharge all courts
And give his bond never to vex us more.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: A hundred pound! 'Las! Take, sir, but threescore.
Do you seek my undoing?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: I'll not bate one sixpence.
I'll maul you, puss, for spitting.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Do thy worst!
Will fourscore stop thy mouth?

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Y'are a slave!
Thou cheat, I'll now tear money from thy throat!
Husband, lay hold on yonder tawny-coat.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Nay, gentlemen, seeing your women are so hot,
I must lose my hair in their company, I see. [Removes his wig.]

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: His hair sheds off, and yet he speaks not so much in the nose as he did before.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: He has had the better chirurgeon. Master Greenwit, is your wit so raw as to play no better a part than a sumner's?

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: I pray who plays a knack to know an honest man in this company?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Dear husband, pardon me, I did dissemble,
Told thee I was his precontracted wife,
When letters came from him for thirty pound;
I had no shift but that.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: But able to make me lousy. On.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: Husband, I pluck'd,
When he had tempted me to think well of him,
[Gelt] feathers from thy wings to make him fly
More lofty.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: A' the top of you, wife. On.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS GALLIPOT
sp.l: He, having wasted them, comes now for more,
Using me as a ruffian doth his whore,
Whose sin keeps him in breath. By heaven I vow
Thy bed he never wrong'd, more than he does now.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: My bed? Ha, ha, like enough: a shop-board will serve
To have a cuckold's coat cut out upon.
Of that we'll talk hereafter. Y'are a villain.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: Hear me but speak, sir, you shall find me none.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: Pray, sir, be patient and hear him.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: I am muzzled
For biting, sir; use me how you will.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: The first hour that your wife was in my eye,
Myself with other gentlemen sitting by
In your shop tasting smoke, and speech being used,
That men who have fairest wives are most abused
And hardly scap'd the horn, your wife maintain'd
That only such spots in city dames were stain'd,
Justly, but by men's slanders: for her own part,
She vow'd that you had so much of her heart;
No man by all his wit, by any wile
Never so fine spun, should yourself beguile
Of what in her was yours.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Yet Pru, 'tis well.
Play out your game at Irish, sir. Who wins?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS OPENWORK
sp.l: The trial is when she comes to bearing.

sp.speaker: LAXTON
sp.l: I scorn'd one woman thus should brave all men
And, which more vex'd me, a she-citizen.
Therefore I laid siege to her; out she held,
Gave many a brave repulse, and me compell'd
With shame to sound retreat to my hot lust.
Then seeing all base desires rak'd up in dust,
And that to tempt her modest ears, I swore
Ne'er to presume again. She said her eye
Would ever give me welcome honestly,
And since I was a gentleman, if it run low,
She would my state relieve, not to o'erthrow
Your own and hers; did so. Then seeing I wrought
Upon her meekness, me she set at nought,
And yet to try if I could turn that tide,
You see what stream I strove with. But, sir, I swear
By heaven, and by those hopes men lay up there,
I neither have nor had a base intent
To wrong your bed; what's done is merriment.
Your gold I pay back with this interest:
When I had most power to do't, I wrong'd you least.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: If this no gullery be, sir--

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: No, no, on my life!

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: Then, sir, I am beholden not to you, wife,
But, Master Laxton, to your want of doing ill,
Which it seems you have not. Gentlemen,
Tarry and dine here all.

sp.speaker: OPENWORK
sp.l: Brother, we have a jest
As good as yours to furnish out a feast.

sp.speaker: GALLIPOT
sp.l: We'll crown our table with it. Wife, brag no more
Of holding out: who most brags is most whore.

div.head: [V.i. A street]
div.stage: Enter Jack Dapper, Moll, Sir Beauteous Ganymede, and Sir Thomas Long.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: But prithee, Master Captain Jack, be plain and perspicuous with me: was it your Meg of Westminster's courage that rescued me from the Poultry puttocks indeed?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: The valour of my wit, I ensure you, sir, fetch'd you off bravely when you were i' the forlorn hope among those desperates. Sir Beauteous Ganymede here and Sir Thomas Long heard that cuckoo, my man Trapdoor, sing the note of your ransom from captivity.

sp.speaker: SIR BEAUTEOUS
sp.l: 'Uds so, Moll, where's that Trapdoor?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Hang'd I think by this time: a justice in this town that speaks nothing but "make a mittimus , away with him to Newgate" used that rogue like a firework to run upon a line betwixt him and me.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: How, how?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Marry, to lay trains of villainy to blow up my life; I smelt the powder, spied what linstock gave fire to shoot against the poor captain of the galley-foist, and away slid I my man, like a shovel-board shilling. He struts up and down the suburbs, I think, and eats up whores, feeds upon a bawd's garbage.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.l: Sirrah Jack Dapper.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: What sayst Tom Long?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.l: Thou hadst a sweet-fac'd boy, hail-fellow with thee to your little Gull. How is he spent?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Troth, I whistled the poor little buzzard off a' my fist, because when he waited upon me at the ordinaries, the gallants hit me i' the teeth still, and said I look'd like a painted alderman's tomb, and the boy at my elbow like a death's head. Sirrah Jack, Moll.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: What says my little Dapper?

sp.speaker: SIR BEAUTEOUS
sp.l: Come, come, walk and talk, walk and talk.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Moll and I'll be i' the midst.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: These knights shall have squires' places, belike then. Well, Dapper, what say you?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Sirrah Captain Mad Mary, the gull my own father, Dapper Sir Davy, laid these London boot-halers, the catchpoles, in ambush to set upon me.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: Your father? Away, Jack!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: By the tassels of this handkercher, 'tis true. And what was his warlike stratagem, think you? He thought because a wicker cage tames a nightingale, a lousy prison could make an ass of me.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: A nasty plot.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Ay, as though a counter, which is a park in which all the wild beasts of the city run head by head, could tame me. Enter the Lord Noland.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Yonder comes my Lord Noland.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: Save you, my lord.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.l: Well met gentlemen all, good Sir Beauteous Ganymede, Sir Thomas Long. And how does Master Dapper?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Thanks, my lord.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: No tobacco, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.l: No, faith, Jack.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: My Lord Noland, will you go to Pimlico with us? We are making a boon voyage to that nappy land of spice-cakes.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.l: Here's such a merry ging, I could find in my heart to sail to the world's end with such company. Come, gentlemen, let's on.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Here's most amorous weather, my lord.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: Amorous weather? They walk.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Is not amorous a good word? Enter Trapdoor like a poor soldier with a patch o'er one eye, and Tearcat with him, all tatters.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Shall we set upon the infantry, these troops of foot? Zounds, yonder comes Moll, my whorish master and mistress! Would I had her kidneys between my teeth.

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.l: I had rather have a cow-heel.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Zounds, I am so patch'd up, she cannot discover me; we'll on.

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.l: Alla corago then.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Good your honours and worships, enlarge the ears of commiseration and let the sound of a hoarse military organ-pipe, penetrate your pitiful bowels to extract out of them so many small drops of silver, as may give a hard straw-bed lodging to a couple of maim'd soldiers.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: Where are you maim'd?

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.l: In both our nether limbs.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Come, come, Dapper, let's give 'em something. 'Las, poor men, what money have you? By my troth, I love a soldier with my soul.

sp.speaker: SIR BEAUTEOUS
sp.p: Stay, stay, where have you serv'd?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.l: In any part of the Low Countries?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Not in the Low Countries, if it please your manhood, but in Hungary against the Turk at the siege of Belgrade.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.l: Who serv'd there with you, sirrah?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Many Hungarians, Moldavians, Walachians, and Transylvanians, with some Sclavonians, and retiring home, sir, the Venetian galleys took us prisoners, yet freed us and suffered us to beg up and down the country.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: You have ambled all over Italy then?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Oh, sir, from Venice to Roma, Vecchio, Bononia, Romania, Bolonia, Modena, Piacenza, and Tuscana with all her cities, as Pistoia, Valteria, Mountepulchena, Arezzo with the Siennois, and diverse others.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Mere rogues: put spurs to 'em once more.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Thou look'st like a strange creature, a fat butter-box, yet speak'st English. What are thou?

p.stage: Ick, mine here? Ick bin den ruffling Tearcat, den brave soldado; ick bin dorick all Dutchlant gueresen: der shellum das meere ine beasa ine woert gaeb. Ick slaag um stroakes on tom cop: dastick den hundred touzun divell halle frollick, mine here.

sp.speaker: SIR BEAUTEOUS
sp.p: Here, here, let's be rid of their jobbering.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Not a cross, Sir Beauteous. You base rogues, I have taken measure of you better than a tailor can, and I'll fit you as you, monster with one eye, have fitted me.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Your worship will not abuse a soldier?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Soldier? Thou deserv'st to be hang'd up by that tongue which dishonours so noble a profession. Soldier, you skeldering varlet? Hold, stand, there should be a trapdoor hereabouts. Pull off his patch.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: The balls of these glaziers of mine, mine eyes, shall be shot up and down in any hot piece of service for my invincible mistress.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: I did not think there had been such knavery in black patches, as now I see.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Oh, sir, he hath been brought up in the Isle of Dogs, and can both fawn like a spaniel and bite like a mastiff as he finds occasion.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.p: What are you, sirrah? A bird of this feather too?

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.p: A man beat'n from the wars, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: I think so, for you never stood to fight.

sp.speaker: DAPPER
sp.p: What's thy name, fellow soldier?

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.p: I am call'd by those that have seen my valour, Tearcat.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.p: Tearcat?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: A mere whip-jack, and that is, in the commonwealth of rogues, a slave that can talk of sea-fight, name all your chief pirates, discover more countries to you than either the Dutch, Spanish, French, or English ever found out, yet indeed all his service is by land, and that is to rob a fair or some such venturous exploit. Tearcat! Foot, sirrah, I have your name now! I remember me in my book of horners horns for the thumb, you know how.

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.p: No indeed, Captain Moll, for I know you by sight: I am no such nipping Christian, but a maunderer upon on the pad, I confess, and meeting with honest Trapdoor here, whom you had cashier'd from bearing arms, out at elbows under your colours, I instructed him in the rudiments of roguery, and by my map made him sail over any country you can name, so that now he can maunder better then myself.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: So then, Trapdoor, thou art turn'd soldier now.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Alas, sir, now there's no wars, 'tis the safest course of life I could take.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: I hope then you can cant, for by your cudgels, you, sirrah, are an upright man.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: As any walks the highway, I assure you.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: And Tearcat, what are you? A wild rogue, an angler, or a ruffler?

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.p: Brother to this upright man, flesh and blood, ruffling Tearcat is my name, and a ruffler is my style, my title, my profession.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Sirrah, where's your doxy? Halt not with me.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.p: Doxy, Moll? What's that?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: His wench.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: My doxy? I have, by the salomon, a doxy that carries a kinchin mort in her slate at her back, besides my dell and my dainty wild dell, with all whom I'll tumble this next darkmans in the strommel, and drink ben [booze], and eat a fat gruntling cheat, a cackling cheat, and a quacking cheat.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Here's old cheating.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: My doxy stays for me in a boozing ken, brave captain.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: He says his wench stays for him in an alehouse. You are no pure rogues.

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.p: Pure rogues? No, we scorn to be pure rogues, but if you come to our lib ken, or our stalling ken, you shall find neither him nor me a queer cuffin.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: So, sir, no churl of you.

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.p: No, but a ben cove, a brave cove, a gentry cuffin.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.p: Call you this canting?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Zounds, I'll give a schoolmaster half a crown a week, and teach me this pedlar's French.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Do but stroll, sir, half a harvest with us, sir, and you shall gabble your bellyful.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Come, you rogue, cant with me.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Well said, Moll. Cant with her, sirrah, and you shall have money, else not a penny.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: I'll have a bout if she please.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Come on, sirrah.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Ben mort, shall you and I heave a booth, mill a ken, or nip a bung? And then we'll couch a hogshead under the ruffmans, and there you shall wap with me, and I'll niggle with you.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: [Slapping and kicking him] Out, you damn'd, impudent rascal!

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Cut benar whids, and hold your fambles and your stamps.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.p: Nay, nay, Moll, why art thou angry? What was his gibberish?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Marry, this, my lord, says he: ben mort, good wench, shall you and I heave a booth, mill a ken, or nip a bung? Shall you and I rob a house or cut a purse?

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: And then we'll couch a hogshead under the ruffmans: and then we'll lie under a hedge.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: That was my desire, captain, as 'tis fit a soldier should lie.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: And there you shall wap with me and I'll niggle with you, and that's all!

sp.speaker: SIR BEAUTEOUS
sp.p: Nay, nay, Moll, what's that wap?

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: Nay, teach me what niggling is; I'd fain be niggling.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Wapping and niggling is all one, the rogue my man can tell you.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: 'Tis fadoodling, if it please you.

sp.speaker: SIR BEAUTEOUS
sp.p: This is excellent. One fit more, good Moll.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Come, you rogue, sing with me.
sp.l: A gage of ben rom-booze
sp.p: In a boozing ken of Romville
TEARCAT. Is benar than a caster,
Peck, pannam, [lap] or popler,
Which we mill in deuse a [vill].
[MOLL, TEARCAT]. Oh, I would lib all the lightmans,
Oh, I would lib all the darkmans,
By the salomon, under the ruffmans,
By the salomon, in the hartmans!
TEARCAT. And scour the queer cramp-ring,
And couch till a palliard docked my dell,
So my boozy nab might skew rom-booze well.
[MOLL, TEARCAT]. Avast to the pad, let us bing,
Avast to the pad, let us bing.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.p: Fine knaves, i'faith!

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.p: The grating of ten new cartwheels and the gruntling of five hundred hogs coming from Romford market cannot make a worse noise than this canting language does in my ears. Pray, my Lord Noland, let's give these soldiers their pay.

sp.speaker: SIR BEAUTEOUS
sp.p: Agreed, and let them march.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.p: [Giving her money] Here, Moll.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Now I see that you are stall'd to the rogue and are not ashamed of your professions. [Giving Tearcat and Trapdoor the money] Look you, my Lord Noland here and these gentlemen bestows upon you two two boards and a half, that's two shillings sixpence.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Thanks to your lordship.

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.p: Thanks, heroical captain.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: We shall cut ben whids of your masters and mistress-ship wheresoever we come.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: You'll maintain, sirrah, the old justice's plot to his face?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Else trine me on the cheats, hang me.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Be sure you meet me there.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.p: Without any more maundering I'll do't. Follow, brave Tearcat.

sp.speaker: TEARCAT
sp.p: I prae, sequor , let us go mouse. Exeunt they two, manet the rest.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.p: Moll, what was in that canting song?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Troth, my lord, only a praise of good drink, the only milk which these wild beasts love to suck, and thus it was:
sp.l: A rich cup of wine,
Oh, it is juice divine,
More wholesome for the head
Than meat, drink, or bread
To fill my drunken pate!
With that, I'd sit up late;
By the heels would I lie,
Under a lousy hedge die.
Let a slave have a pull
At my whore, so I be full
Of that precious liquor--
sp.p: And a parcel of such stuff, my lord, not worth the opening. Enter a Cutpurse very gallant, with four or five men after him, one with a wand.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.p: What gallant comes yonder?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Mass, I think I know him: 'tis one of Cumberland.

sp.speaker: FIRST CUTPURSE
sp.p: Shall we venture to shuffle in amongst yon heap of gallants and strike?

sp.speaker: SECOND CUTPURSE
sp.p: 'Tis a question whether there be any silver shells amongst them for all their satin outsides.

sp.speaker: OMNES [CUTPURSES]
sp.p: Let's try.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Pox on him! A gallant? Shadow me, I know him: 'tis one that cumbers the land indeed; if he swim near to the shore of any of your pockets, look to your purses.

sp.speaker: OMNES [WITH MOLL]
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: This brave fellow is no better than a foist.

sp.speaker: OMNES [WITH MOLL]
sp.p: Foist? What's that?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: A diver with two fingers, a pickpocket: all his train study the figging law, that's to say, cutting of purses and foisting. One of them is a nip; I took him once i' the twopenny gallery at the Fortune. Then there's a cloyer, or snap, that dogs any new brother in that trade, and snaps will have half in any booty. He with the wand is both a stale, whose office is to face a man i' the streets whilst shells are drawn by another, and then with his black conjuring rod in his hand, he, by the nimbleness of his eye and juggling-stick, will in cheaping a piece of plate at a goldsmith's stall, make four or five rings mount from the top of his caduceus, and, as if it were at leap-frog, they skip into his hand presently.

sp.speaker: SECOND CUTPURSE
sp.p: Zounds, we are smok'd!

sp.speaker: OMNES [CUTPURSES]
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: SECOND CUTPURSE
sp.p: We are boil'd. Pox on her! See, Moll, the roaring drab.

sp.speaker: FIRST CUTPURSE
sp.p: All the diseases of sixteen hospitals boil her! Away!

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Bless you, sir.

sp.speaker: FIRST CUTPURSE
sp.p: And you, good sir.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Dost not ken me, man?

sp.speaker: FIRST CUTPURSE
sp.p: No, [trust] me, sir.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Heart, there's a knight to whom I'm bound for many favours lost his purse at the last new play i' the Swan, seven angels in't. Make it good; you're best. Do you see? No more.

sp.speaker: FIRST CUTPURSE
sp.p: A synagogue shall be call'd, Mistress Mary; disgrace me not. Pacus palabros, I will conjure for you. Farewell. [Exeunt Cutpurses.]

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.p: Did not I tell you, my lord?

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.p: I wonder how thou cam'st to the knowledge of these nasty villains.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: And why do the foul mouths of the world call thee Moll Cutpurse? A name, methinks, damn'd and odious.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Dare any step forth to my face and say,
"I have ta'en thee doing so, Moll," I must confess,
In younger days, when I was apt to stray,
I have sat amongst such adders, seen their stings
As any here might, and in full playhouses
Watch'd their quick-diving hands to bring to shame
Such rogues, and in that stream met an ill name.
When next, my lord, you spy any one of those,
So he be in his art a scholar, question him,
Tempt him with gold to open the large book
Of his close villainies, and you yourself shall cant
Better than poor Moll can, and know more laws
Of cheaters, lifters, nips, foists, puggards, curbers,
With all the devil's black guard, than it is fit
Should be discovered to a noble wit.
I know they have their orders, offices,
Circuits and circles unto which they are bound
To raise their own damnation in.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: How dost thou know it?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: As you do: I show it you, they to me show it.
Suppose, my lord, you were in Venice.

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: If some Italian pander there would tell
All the close tricks of courtesans, would not you
Hearken to such a fellow?

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: And here,
Being come from Venice, to a friend most dear
That were to travel thither, you would proclaim
Your knowledge in those villainies to save
Your friend from their quick danger. Must you have
A black, ill name because ill things you know?
Good troth, my lord, I am made Moll Cutpurse so.
How many are whores in small ruffs and still looks!
How many chaste whose names fill slander's books!
Were all men cuckolds, whom gallants in their scorns
Call so, we should not walk for goring horns.
Perhaps for my mad going some reprove me:
I please myself and care not else who loves me.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: A brave mind, Moll, i'faith.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.l: Come, my lord, shall's to the ordinary?

sp.speaker: LORD NOLAND
sp.l: Ay, 'tis noon sure.

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Good my lord, let not my name condemn me to you or to the world. A fencer I hope may be call'd a coward: is he so for that? If all that have ill names in London were to be whipp'd and to pay but twelvepence apiece to the beadle, I would rather have his office than a constable's.

sp.speaker: JACK
sp.l: So would I, Captain Moll: 'twere a sweet, tickling office, i'faith.

div.head: [V.ii. Sir Alexander's house]
div.stage: Enter Sir Alexander Wengrave, Goshawk and Greenwit, and others.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: My son marry a thief, that impudent girl,
Whom all the world stick their worst eyes upon?

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: How will your care prevent it?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: 'Tis impossible.
They marry close; they're gone, but none knows whither.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Oh, gentlemen, when has a father's heart-strings
Held out so long from breaking?
Now what news, sir?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: They were met upo' th' water an hour since, sir,
Putting in towards the Sluice. [Exit Servant.]

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: The Sluice? Come, gentlemen,
'Tis Lambeth works against us.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: And that Lambeth
Joins more mad matches than your six wet towns
'Twixt that and Windsor Bridge, where fares lie soaking.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Delay no time, sweet gentlemen: to Blackfriars!
We'll take a pair of oars and make after 'em. Enter Trapdoor.

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: Your son and that bold masculine ramp,
My mistress, are landed now at Tower.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Hoyda, at Tower?

sp.speaker: TRAPDOOR
sp.l: I heard it now reported. [Exit Trapdoor.]

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Which way gentlemen shall I bestow my care?
I'm drawn in pieces betwixt deceit and shame. Enter Sir [Guy] Fitzallard.

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: Sir Alexander,
You're well met and most rightly served:
My daughter was a scorn to you.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Say not so, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: A very abject she, poor gentlewoman;
Your house [has] been dishonoured. Give you joy, sir,
Of your son's gaskin-bride; you'll be a grandfather shortly
To a fine crew of roaring sons and daughters:
'Twill help to stock the suburbs passing well, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Oh, play not with the miseries of my heart!
Wounds should be dress'd and heal'd, not vex'd or left
Wide open to the anguish of the patient,
And scornful air let in: rather let pity
And advice charitably help to refresh 'em.

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: Who'd place his charity so unworthily
Like one that gives alms to a cursing beggar?
Had I but found one spark of goodness in you
Toward my deserving child, which then grew fond
Of your son's virtues, I had eased you now;
But I perceive both fire of youth and goodness
Are rak'd up in the ashes of your age,
Else no such shame should have come near your house,
Nor such ignoble sorrow touch your heart.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: If not for worth, for pity's sake, assist me.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: You urge a thing past sense. How can he help you?
All his assistance is as frail as ours,
Full as uncertain. Where's the place that holds 'em?
One brings us water-news; then comes another
With a full-charg'd mouth, like a culverin's voice,
And he reports the Tower. Whose sounds are truest?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: In vain you flatter him, Sir Alexander.
I flatter him! Gentlemen, you wrong me grossly.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: He does it well, i'faith.

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: Both news are false
Of Tower or water: they took no such way yet.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Oh, strange! Hear you this, gentlemen: yet more plunges?

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: Th' are nearer than you think for, yet more close
Than if they were further off.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: How am I lost
In these distractions!

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: In taxing me for rashness, 'fore you all
I will engage my state to half his wealth,
Nay, to his son's revenues, which are less,
And yet nothing at all till they come from him,
That I could, if my will stuck to my power,
Prevent this marriage yet, nay, banish her
Forever from his thoughts, much more his arms.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Slack not this goodness, though you heap upon me
Mountains of malice and revenge hereafter:
I'd willingly resign up half my state to him,
So he would marry the mean'st drudge I hire.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: He talks impossibilities, and you believe 'em.

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: I talk no more than I know how to finish;
My fortunes else are his that dares stake with me.
The poor young gentleman I love and pity,
And to keep shame from him, because the spring
Of his affection was my daughter's first
Till his frown blasted all, do but estate him
In those possessions which your love and care
Once pointed out for him, that he may have room
To entertain fortunes of noble birth,
Where now his desperate wants casts him upon her;
And if I do not for his own sake chiefly
Rid him of this disease that now grows on him,
I'll forfeit my whole state before these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Troth, but you shall not undertake such matches;
We'll persuade so much with you.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Here's my ring;
He will believe this token. 'Fore these gentlemen
I will confirm it fully: all those lands
My first love 'lotted him he shall straight possess
In that refusal.

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: If I change it not,
Change me into a beggar.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Are you mad, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Will you undo yourself by doing,
And show a prodigal trick in your old days?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: 'Tis a match, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: SIR GUY
sp.l: Ay, ay, sir, ay.
I ask no favour, trust to you for none;
My hope rests in the goodness of your son. Exit [Sir Guy] Fitzallard.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: He holds it up well yet.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Of an old knight, i'faith.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Curs'd be the time I laid his first love barren,
Willfully barren, that before this hour
Had sprung forth fruits of comfort and of honour!
He lov'd a virtuous gentlewoman. Enter Moll [in man's clothes].

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Life,
Here's Moll!

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Jack?

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: How dost thou, Jack?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: How dost thou, gallant?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Impudence, where's my son?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: Weakness, go look him.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Is this your wedding gown?

sp.speaker: MOLL
sp.l: The man talks monthly:
Hot broth and a dark chamber for the knight;
I see he'll be stark mad at our next meeting. Exit Moll.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Why, sir, take comfort now, there's no such matter:
No priest will marry her, sir, for a woman
Whiles that shape's on, and it was never known
Two men were married and conjoin'd in one.
Your son hath made some shift to love another.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Whate'er she be, she has my blessing with her.
May they be rich and fruitful, and receive
Like comfort to their issue as I take
In them; h'as pleas'd me now, marrying not this:
Through a whole world he could not choose amiss.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Glad y'are so penitent for your former sin, sir.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: Say he should take a wench with her smock-dowry,
No portion with her but her lips and arms?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Why, who thrive better, sir? They have most blessing,
Though other have more wealth, and least repent:
Many that want most know the most content.

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Say he should marry a kind, youthful sinner?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Age will quench that: any offence but theft
And drunkenness, nothing but death can wipe away;
Their sins are green even when their heads are grey.
Nay, I despair not now; my heart's cheer'd, gentlemen:
No face can come unfortunately to me.
Now, sir, your news?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: Your son with his fair bride
Is near at hand.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Fair may their fortunes be!

sp.speaker: GREENWIT
sp.l: Now you're resolv'd, sir, it was never she?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: I find it in the music of my heart.
sp.stage: Enter Moll mask'd, in Sebastian's hand, and [Sir Guy] Fitzallard.
sp.l: See where they come.

sp.speaker: GOSHAWK
sp.l: A proper lusty presence, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Now has he pleas'd me right: I always counsell'd him
To choose a goodly, personable creature;
Just of her pitch was my first wife his mother.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Before I dare discover my offence,
I kneel for pardon.

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: My heart gave it thee
Before thy tongue could ask it.
Rise; thou hast rais'd my joy to greater height
Than to that seat where grief dejected it.
Both welcome to my love and care forever,
Hide not my happiness too long, all's pardoned.
Here are our friends. Salute her, gentlemen. They unmask her.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.l: Heart! Who['s] this? Moll?

sp.speaker: SIR ALEXANDER
sp.l: Oh, my reviving shame! Is't I must live
To be struck blind? Be it the work of sorrow,
